    Structure–Activity Relationships of Novel Thiazole-Based Modafinil Analogues Acting at Monoamine Transporters

    SUBJECTS:
    • Inhibitors,

    • Phenyls
    Get e-Alerts

    Abstract

    Atypical dopamine reuptake inhibitors, such as modafinil, are used for the treatment of sleeping disorders and investigated as potential therapeutics against cocaine addiction and for cognitive enhancement. Our continuous effort to find modafinil analogues with higher inhibitory activity on and selectivity toward the dopamine transporter (DAT) has previously led to the promising thiazole-containing derivatives CE-103, CE-111, CE-123, and CE-125. Here, we describe the synthesis and activity of a series of compounds based on these scaffolds, which resulted in several new selective DAT inhibitors and gave valuable insights into the structure–activity relationships. Introduction of the second chiral center and subsequent chiral separations provided all four stereoisomers, whereby the S-configuration on both generally exerted the highest activity and selectivity on DAT. The representative compound of this series was further characterized by in silico, in vitro, and in vivo studies that have demonstrated both safety and efficacy profile of this compound class.

    Introduction

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    Modafinil (1) (2-[(diphenylmethyl)sulfinyl]acetamide by IUPAC nomenclature) is an innovative wake-promoting agent initially marketed in France in the early 1990s for the treatment of narcolepsy (Figure 1).(1) In 1998, it was approved by the United States Food and Drug Administration (FDA) as a novel agent to treat daytime sleepiness caused by narcolepsy or by shift work sleep disorder.(2) In the U.S., military research in modafinil as potential alternative to amphetamines for enhancing alertness and reducing battle fatigue is ongoing, and its use in Air Force missions has already been approved.(3,4) Along with methylphenidate, it gained high popularity in the past decade among shift workers, students, and others, who are taking these drugs as nootropics to improve performance during the exams or in the work place.(3−5) Although the media attention has diminished lately, it was not the case with off-label use of modafinil as a cognitive-enhancing drug. Indeed, the results of two surveys recently published in JAMA reveal high use of modafinil among German surgeons and undergraduates of the University of Maryland.(5) Due to its reported low abuse liability, modafinil has also been suggested for the treatment of mental illnesses such as attention-deficit/hyperactivity disorder (ADHD).(6)
    Modafinil is a racemic mixture of the R- and S-enantiomers in equimolar ratio (1:1), while R-modafinil (FDA approved in June 2007) is a pure enantiomer, which displays slightly increased pharmacological potency as a wakefulness-inducing agent compared to the racemic mixture.(7,8) The difference is more obvious in the pharmacokinetic profile as pointed out by recent human studies that showed that R-modafinil is the metabolically more stable and longer-acting enantiomer.(9)
    Despite being brought to the market 2 decades ago, modafinil’s mode of action remained unknown and controversially discussed for years.(2,10) Studies using radioligand binding assays (Mignot et al.,(11) 1994) as well as cell-based (Madras et al., 2006) and synaptosome-based uptake inhibition assays (Zolkowska et al., 2009) have identified the dopamine transporter (DAT) as a major target to which modafinil binds.(12,13) It was Loland et al. who have provided more detailed insight into modafinil’s mode of action. They confirmed that modafinil and both of its enantiomers inhibit dopamine reuptake in a cell-based assay, with the R-enantiomer being almost 3-fold more potent than the S-enantiomer. In the same study, they have also demonstrated that the binding site for modafinil and the central binding site for dopamine overlap and that R- and S-modafinil preferentially bind to a different DAT conformational isomer than cocaine.(14) Furthermore, modafinil does not act as a substrate for DAT and does not cause efflux of dopamine, a hallmark that clearly distinguishes it̀s pharmacological profile from those of amphetamine and amphetamine-like psychostimulants.(15−17) Owing to its unique binding mode and exclusive pharmacological profile, modafinil has been classified as an atypical dopamine reuptake inhibitor.(14,18)
    These findings made modafinil an interesting scaffold for medicinal chemistry, leading to a large number of derivatives that have been synthesized and tested for their biological activity in the recent years.(6,7,19−22) In particular, much of the work in the United States has focused on development of modafinil analogues as potential therapeutics against cocaine addiction.(20) From this research, compound JJC8-016 (2) has emerged as an atypical dopamine reuptake inhibitor that has no cocaine-like abuse potential (Figure 1).(23,24) An independent line of research has focused on the activity of modafinil and its analogues in animal paradigms of working and spatial memory.(25−33)
    We have previously reported a series of modafinil derivatives in which the carboxamide moiety has been replaced with various five- and six-membered aromatic heterocycles.(34) Compounds of this series have demonstrated (I) higher activity and better selectivity toward DAT than modafinil when tested by reuptake inhibition assay, (II) absence of amphetamine- and cocaine-like properties when tested in efflux and binding assays, as well as (III) absence of neurotoxicity when tested in vivo.(34) In addition, carboxamide replacement with substituted and unsubstituted thiazoles led to the discovery of compounds with an improved in vitro and in vivo profile.(30−33) For example, CE-103 (3) exerted comparable in vitro activity on DAT (IC50 = 15 μM) as modafinil, with negligible effects on serotonin and norepinephrine transporter (SERT and NET) and it was able to decrease working memory errors in the radial arm maze (RAM) significantly at doses of 1 mg/kg and 10 mg/kg body weight when given intraperitoneally compared to vehicle control (Figure 1).(30) Similarly, CE-111 (4) and CE-125 (5) showed higher reuptake inhibition activity on DAT (IC50 = 3.2 μM and 4.1 μM, respectively) compared to modafinil and negligible activity on SERT and NET (Figure 1). Both compounds were able to improve the memory performance on the 8th and 9th day on the RAM at 1 mg/kg body weight (ip) and on the 8th, 9th, and 10th day at 10 mg/kg (ip) when compared to the control group.(31,32) Another thiazole-containing analogue, CE-123 (6), was previously shown to inhibit dopamine reuptake (IC50 = 4.6 μM) while showing almost negligible effects on reuptake of dopamine and serotonin in vitro. As compared to R-modafinil, it reached higher concentrations in the brain and had a smaller elimination rate. In vivo drug efficacy of CE-123 was demonstrated in male Sprague-Dawley rats in hole-board task, a spatial memory paradigm. The compound was able to enhance both memory acquisition as well as memory retrieval.(33) Interestingly, the S-enantiomer of CE-123 showed an almost 8-fold higher in vitro activity on DAT than the R-enantiomer. In male rats, S-CE-123 demonstrated increased cognitive flexibility with diminished impulsivity compared to R-modafinil as determined by an attentional set-shifting task (ASST) and a five-choice serial-reaction time task (5-CSRTT).(35)
    On the basis of the above-described results, the aim of this study was to generate a novel series of modafinil analogues with further improved activity and selectivity toward DAT. To that end, the structure–activity relationship (SAR) on DAT, SERT,and NET was explored by replacing the carboxamide function of modafinil with a series of substituted and unsubstituted thiazoles and by modifying the diphenylmethyl group. We also sought to explore the influence of introducing one additional chiral center on the activity of such analogues. The four pure stereoisomers of such an analogue were obtained, their absolute configuration was determined by single crystal X-ray diffraction analysis, their reuptake inhibition activity was tested, and the compounds were docked within the binding pocket of human DAT homology model. Furthermore, the compounds of this series were screened by in silico methods for their activity on the hERG channel and the most potent DAT reuptake inhibitors were tested in vitro in order to verify the in silico results. Finally, we have performed a pharmacokinetic study of the most potent analogue.

    Chemistry

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    The synthetic pathway of novel thiazole-containing modafinil analogues without substitution on phenyl rings 12a–s is shown in Scheme 1. The starting compound, diphenylmethyl-S-isothiuronium hydrobromide (9), was alkylated with both plain and substituted 2-, 4-, or 5-(chloromethyl)thiazoles to provide intermediates 11a–s in 31% to >95% yield. Intermediates were subsequently oxidized, and final sulfoxide-containing products 12a–s were obtained in 11% to >95% yield.
    Synthesis of 2-[(9H-fluoren-9-ylsulfinyl)methyl]-1,3-thiazole (17) was achieved via a similar synthetic route as depicted in Scheme 2. The first step involves conversion of 9-hydroxyfluorene (13) with thiourea and 48% HBr to the corresponding thiouronium salt (14). The second step is an alkylation reaction with 2-(chloromethyl)thiazole to give the intermediate (16). The final step is an oxidation reaction in CH3COOH with H2O2 that gave the final product 17 in 67% yield.
    Thiazole-containing analogues with monosubstitution on one or both phenyl rings (24a–m) were obtained as depicted in Scheme 3. Conversion of the chloromethylthiazoles 18a–e with thioacetic acid (19) to yield the acylated intermediates 20a–e and then deprotection and isolation of the desired plane and substituted thiomethylthiazoles 21a–e were the first steps. In the subsequent reaction, 21a–e were condensed with substituted diphenylmethyl alcohols 22a–m to yield intermediates 23a–m (yield 22% to >95%). In the final step, oxidation of the appropriate sulfenyl moiety gave the desired products 24a–m in 11–92% yield.
    Compounds 31c–f were obtained as depicted in Scheme 4. 4-(Chloromethyl)thiazole (18a) was reacted with thioacetic acid (19) to yield acylated compound 20a, which was hydrolyzed under alkaline conditions to corresponding mercaptan 21a. Thiazol-4-ylmethanethiol was further condensed with (4-bromophenyl)(phenyl)methanol (22i) to yield racemic 4-({[(4-bromophenyl)(phenyl)methyl]thio}methyl)thiazole (23i) in 25% yield. In the following step, compound 23i was separated into the enantiomers 30a and 30b using chiral HPLC on a CHIRALPAK IA semipreparative column (10 mm diameter × 20 cm length) (Daicel Inc., Tokyo, Japan) and ACN as the mobile phase. Each of the enantiomers was further oxidized to yield again racemic compounds 31a and 31b, respectively, that were finally separated using CHIRALPACK IA semipreparative column into the individual stereoisomers 31c–f.
    Compounds 24h, 24k, and 24l were separated into individual (less retained and more retained) enantiomers 32a, 32b, 33a, 33b, 34a, and 34b, respectively, by means of chiral-phase high performance liquid chromatography (HPLC).
    Compounds 42a–f to 45a–f were obtained as depicted in Scheme 5. Thiazol-5-ylmethanethiol (36) was reacted with para-monosubstituted diphenyl alcohols (35a–f) to yield racemic monosubstituted sulfide intermediates (37a–f) in 22–87% yield. Each intermediate was separated into individual enantiomers (38a–f and 39a–f), by means of chiral-phase HPLC, that were subsequently oxidized to corresponding sulfoxide-containing derivatives (40a–f and 41a–f) with 81–95% and 76–95% yields, respectively. Racemic products were further separated into individual enantiomers (42a–f, 43a–f, 44a–f, and 45a–f) by another round of chiral-based separations.

    Results and Discssion

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To

    SARs of Racemates on Reuptake Inhibition of Monoamine Transporters

    All sulfoxide-containing end products (12a–i, 11j, 12k–s, 17, 24a–m) were tested for their reuptake inhibition potential on HEK293 cells with stable expression of human DAT, NET, and SERT isoforms, as described in detail under the Experimental Procedures section. The obtained values were compared to those of the parent compounds modafinil (1) (DAT IC50 = 11.5 ± 4.3 μM; NET IC50 = 284 ± 24 μM; SERT, not specific in tested concentration range)(34) and R-modafinil (DAT IC50 = 6.6 ± 0.8 μM; NET IC50 = 170 ± 90 μM; SERT IC50 = 232 ± 197 μM)(25) and correlated to the chemical modifications. SAR study was aimed to elucidate the effect of (i) replacing the carboxamide with various substituted and unsubstituted thiazoles linked via positions 2, 4, and 5 as well as of (ii) introducing substituents on one or both phenyl rings. The results are summarized and presented in Tables 1–3.
    Table 1. Inhibition of hDAT-, hNET-, and hSERT-Mediated Uptake of Respective Radioligands by Thiazole-Containing Analogues (Bridged on Position 4 of Thiazole)a
    a

    IC50 values represent data three independent experiments, each performed in triplicate. NA: not active in used concentration range.

    Heterocyclic replacement of the carboxamide moiety with unsubstituted thiazole on position 4 yielded the compound 12a, which exerted activity (DAT IC50 = 6.7 ± 1.4 μM) comparable to that of R-modafinil and almost 1-fold better than that of 1. Furthermore, this analogue showed negligible activity on NET and SERT (Table 1). Interestingly, most of the racemic compounds herein reported were found not to inhibit the uptake of [3H]-serotonin by SERT, with the exception of weak activity of 12k (SERT IC50 = 201 ± 79 μM) and 24h (SERT IC50 = 221 ± 13 μM).
    Introduction of a methyl group in position 2 yielded the previously reported compound 4 with slightly higher activity on DAT (IC50 = 3.2 μM) than 12a. Substitution on the same position with larger aliphatic groups such as ethyl, n-propyl, isopropyl, and n-butyl yielded analogues 12e (IC50 = 14.6 ± 0.9 μM), 12f (IC50 = 28.4 ± 1.9 μM), 12d (IC50 = 24.3 ± 1.7 μM), and 12g (IC50 = 13.5 ± 2.8 μM), respectively, with decreased activity on DAT. Out of them, only 12g exerted weak activity on NET (IC50 = 164 ± 57 μM). Substitution with a chlorine atom on the same position yielded the selective DAT inhibitor 12i with an activity (IC50 = 3.0 ± 1.0 μM) as good as that of compound 4. Introduction of a five-membered aromatic heterocycle, i.e., thiophene bound through position 2, gave compound 12b with an inhibitory activity on DAT (IC50 = 7.0 ± 2.3 μM) comparable to that of R-modafinil and 12a.
    Further modification of 4 by introducing a second methyl group in position 5 gave compound 12c and led to a significantly decreased activity on DAT. The same was observed upon extension of the bridge to the sulfoxide by exchanging the methylene with an ethylene group as in compound 12h (Table 1).
    Previously, it was reported that the replacement of the sulfoxide moiety with a sulfide function in modafinil analogues may have minor effects on DAT binding but should lead to increased affinities at SERT and NET.(6,20) To evaluate whether our newly synthesized compounds would fall under this concept, compound 11j was tested for monoamine transporters reuptake inhibition activity and compared to its sulfoxide counterpart 4. While we have indeed observed enhanced reuptake inhibition on NET, now activity was detected on SERT and a significantly decreased inhibition activity was measured on DAT (IC50 = 91.4 ± 2.2 μM). On the basis of these findings, none of the other thioether intermediates were tested for bioactivity.
    Compounds 5 and 12a were further modified by introducing substitutions on both para-positions of the phenyl rings. In the case of 12a, substitution with either methyl groups or strong electron-withdrawing groups such as fluorine and chlorine (24f, 24e, and 24a, respectively) only had minor effects on the reuptake inhibition activity on DAT (Table 1). Different results were obtained upon modification of 5, where introduction of chlorine to give 24b yielded a 2- to 3-fold reduced but still good reuptake inhibition activity on DAT (IC50 = 14.0 ± 5.5 μM), while electron-donating methoxy groups, as in 24g, led to a strong drop in activity (DAT IC50 = 105 ± 24 μM) and the methyl groups in 24c completely abolished the activity.
    A much smaller series of compounds was synthesized based on the structure of CE-103 (3), with the thiazole linked via position 2. Introduction of a single methyl group on position 5 as well as of two methyl groups on positions 4 and 5 of the thiazole yielded analogues 12l and 12k, respectively. However, both showed decreased activity on DAT compared to the unsubstituted compound 3 (Table 2). Analogous to 12a, substitution with methyl groups on the para-positions of both phenyl rings (24m) led to a decrease in activity, while substitution with chlorine atoms on the same position (24j) yielded a slightly increased activity on DAT (IC50 = 9.6 ± 1.4 μM), which is similar to those of 1 and R-modafinil. Replacement of the diphenylmethyl with a fluorenyl moiety yielded analogue 17 with no activity on DAT, NET, and SERT. This clearly demonstrates that the free rotation of the phenyl groups is crucial for activity, indicating that they need to be oriented in a nonplanar configuration to fit into the binding pocket of the monoamine transporters.
    Table 2. Inhibition of hDAT-, hNET-, and hSERT-Mediated Uptake of Respective Radioligands by Thiazole-Containing Analogues (Bridged on Position 2 of Thiazole)a
    a

    IC50 values represent data from three independent experiments, each performed in triplicate. NA: not active in used concentration range.

    In the final series, analogues of CE-123 (6) bridged via position 5 of thiazole were explored (Table 3). Introduction of methyl groups either on position 2, 4, or 2 and 4 on the thiazole yielded analogues 12m, 12r, and 12s, respectively, which all showed strongly reduced activity on DAT compared to 1, 6, and R-modafinil. Introduction of both electron-withdrawing and -donating groups on position 2 of the thiazole, as in analogues 12n, 12o, and 12q, also only led to reduction of activity on DAT. More differentiated results were obtained with modifications on the para-positions of both phenyl rings. Compared to 6, strong electron-donating methoxy groups as in 24d strongly decreased the activity on DAT; methyl groups as in 24l and F atoms as in 24k slightly reduced the activity, and strongly electron-withdrawing groups such as Cl led to equal or slightly improved activity as shown for 24h. However, the latter was also moderately active on NET (IC50 = 45.5 ± 4.2 μM) and thus less selective toward DAT. Attaching the bulky adamantyl group to C-2 of the thiazole was performed to probe the available space within the binding pocket, but the obtained analogue 12p showed too low solubility to be tested in biological assays.
    Table 3. Inhibition of hDAT-, hNET-, and hSERT-Mediated Uptake of Respective Radioligands by Thiazole-Containing Analogues (Bridged on Position 5 of Thiazole)a
    a

    IC50 values represent data from three independent experiments, each performed in triplicate. NA: not active in used concentration range. NT: not tested.

    In summary, substituting the carboxamide group of modafinil with various thiazole derivatives while keeping the diphenylmethyl moiety unmodified yielded three additional racemic compounds (12a, 12b, and 12i) that showed selective inhibitory activities toward DAT with an IC50 in the range of 1–10 μM. Interestingly, while the plain thiazoles linked via positions 2, 4, and 5 showed relatively similar activities on DAT with IC50 values of 14.7 μM (CE-103), 6.66 ± 1.44 μM (12a), and 4.61 ± 0.14 μM (CE-123), respectively, they differed strongly upon substitution on the C-atoms of the heterocycle. While all such derivatives of CE-103 and CE-123 showed a severely reduced activity on DAT, 12a can easily accept various substituents on C-2 of thiazole to give analogs with only slightly reduced or even somewhat improved activity (Table 1).
    On the basis of four of the most active structures of above, namely, CE-103, 12a, CE-123, and CE-125, we further tested the effect of symmetric substitution in para-position of the two phenyl rings. This yielded another six analogues (24a, 24e, 24f, 24h, 24j, and 24k) with IC50 values below 10 μM. Unfortunately, only a minor improvement in activity on DAT could be obtained in this way, and even that goes in hand with decreased selectivity when taking into account the activity on NET and SERT.

    SARs of Enantiopure Compounds at DAT, NET, and SERT

    As has been proven for modafinil, where the R-enantiomer is more active, and CE-123, where the S-enantiomer showed an almost 8-fold higher in vitro activity, enantiopure DAT inhibitors can be more active than the racemic mixture. Also, providing solely the more active enantiomer as drug can reduce or abolish side effects if these are mainly caused by the other enantiomer. To test whether the enantiomers of our novel thiazole-based modafinil analogues also show significant differences in their activity, racemic compounds 24h, 24k, and 24l were separated by chiral-phase HPLC. In all three cases, there was indeed a big difference, ranging from approximately ∼4-fold to ∼50-fold, in the activity of the two enantiomers (Table 4). 32a, 32b, and 33b could be successfully crystallized and their absolute configuration was determined by single crystal X-ray diffraction analysis, showing that at least for two more compounds of this series the S-configuration of the sulfoxide yields the higher activity.
    Table 4. Inhibition of hDAT-, hNET-, and hSERT-Mediated Uptake of Respective Radioligands by Single Stereoisomers of Thiazole-Containing Analoguesa
    a

    Configurations given in parentheses are indirectly determined by measuring only the other stereoisomer(s). IC50 values represent data from three independent experiments, each performed in triplicate. NA: not active in used concentration range.

    In our previous study, we aimed to explore the influence of introducing an additional chiral center into a thiophene-containing modafinil analogue on its activity toward monoamine transporters. However, despite promising results for one pure stereoisomer, lack of a complete data set for all four separated stereoisomers due to very low solubility of some of them prevented a fully conclusive analysis.(34) Thus, the same strategy was applied to two of the better soluble thiazole-containing modafinil analogues. CE-123 was modified by introduction of either a methoxy, methyl, fluoro, chloro, bromo, or trifluoromethyl group on the para-position of only one of the phenyl rings. The individual stereoisomers were tested, and where possible, the absolute configuration was determined (Table 4).
    Again, the four stereoisomers of each of the six analogous showed remarkable differences in both activity and selectivity, and in every case, the most active stereoisomer was more promising in terms of activity and selectivity than the corresponding symmetrically modified analogues. For this set of very similar compounds, general trends are seen regarding the effect of the configuration on both the S and the C atoms. Those stereoisomers, shown to have S-configuration on both atoms (S,S), showed the highest activity on DAT, followed by the molecules with S-configuration on the sulfoxide and R-configuration on the chiral carbon (S,R). In all cases, the R,S-configuration gave by far the lowest activity. For optimization of the selectivity, it is interesting that the SAR is different regarding activity on DAT, NET, and SERT. The SERT is nearly exclusively inhibited by the R,R-stereoisomers, and 43d actually inhibits SERT more effectively than DAT. The trend for NET is much less clear, but usually S,S-stereoisomers, which are most active on DAT, did also hit NET but with lower IC50 values. Surprisingly, the most promising CE-123 derivative tested so far, which possesses a single Br-atom in para-position of one of the phenyls and S,S-configuration (42e), shows neglectable activity on NET while inhibiting DAT with an IC50 of only 1.6 ± 0.6 μM.
    To test if these findings can be translated to the thiazole-containing analogues bridged on position 4 of thiazole, i.e., CE-111, CE-125, and 12a, the H atom in para-position of one of the phenyl rings of 12a was substituted by a Br atom. Already the racemic mixture showed improved activity on DAT (IC50 = 1.85 ± 1.20 μM). Chiral HPLC separation of the racemic thioether intermediate 30, followed by introduction of the second chiral center by oxidation of the sulfur, and another chiral HPLC separation gave individual stereoisomers 31c–f (Scheme 4). The SAR regarding the configuration on the two chiral centers was nearly the same as described above except that here the R,R-stereoisomer was more active on DAT than the S,R-stereoisomer. 31e, which was demonstrated by single crystal X-ray diffraction analysis to have S,S-configuration, showed the highest activity on DAT (IC50 = 0.65 ± 0.07 μM) of all tested compounds in this series while being at the same time 100-fold less active on NET (IC50 = 73 ± 9 μM) and exerting negligible activity on SERT (Figure 2).
    With its submicromolar activity, 31e is a 10-fold more potent DAT inhibitor compared to R-modafinil and almost 20-fold more active than modafinil. For these reasons, 31e was selected for further characterization.

    Molecular Docking of the Four Stereoisomers 31c–f

    An overlay of the best scored docking poses of compounds 31c–f in the binding pocket of an hDAT homology model is shown in Figure 3. The poses are very similar with the exception of 31d, which orientates differently in the binding pocket. The interaction patterns of the four stereoisomers of 31c–f are shown in Figure 4. What should be highlighted is that the interaction between the transporter and all four ligands is mostly governed by the interaction between primarily hydrophobic amino acids and the phenyl rings of molecules 31c–f. The exception is the observation of an additional hydrogen bond interaction between 31d and Ser149.
    In general, it can be said that from the position of the ligand in the binding pocket and the mostly entropic governed interactions, methods that incorporate entropic contributions (e.g., relative binding free energy) might be needed for further lead development.

    In Silico hERG Channel Activity Profiling

    The Inte:Ligand Tox Pharmacophore DB(50) was used for toxicity profiling of all 37 synthesized compounds, but no significant effect on hERG channel was predicted for any of them (Figure 5).

    In Vitro Effect of 31c–f on Action Potential Parameters

    In order to investigate the effect of enantiopure analogues 31c–f on action potential (AP) parameters, the APs of Cor.4U hiPSC-CMs cells in the presence of 0.01, 0.1, 1, or 10 μM 31c–f were measured by means of a voltage-sensitive fluorescence dye. As shown in Figure 6, none of the tested compounds caused early after depolarizations (EADs) or changes in action potential duration or shape even when applied at 10 μM concentration.

    Effect of 31e on Dopamine Release

    In superfusion experiments on HEK293 cells stably expressing the human DAT preloaded with the metabolically inert transporter substrate [3H]1-methyl-4-phenylpyridinium ([3H]MPP+) 3 μM d-amphetamine increased tritium efflux (Figure 7, circles) whereas 10 μM 31e suppressed efflux (Figure 7, squares) and blocked d-amphetamine-induced release (Figure 7 triangles). Thus, 31e did not induce reverse transport as elicited by the prototypic releasing drug d-amphetamine but acted as a pure uptake inhibitory drug blocking the reverse transport induced by d-amphetamine. The inhibitory action of 31e on basal efflux of [3H]MPP+ may be due to a blockade of a basal DAT-mediated efflux of the transporter substrate observed under our experimental conditions.

    In Vitro Neurotoxicity of 31e

    Compound 31e was evaluated in the neurite outgrowth assay using cryopreserved rat cortical neurons (QBM Cell Science), and the evaluation was performed by Cyprotex (Massachusetts, USA, Study Number CYP2052-R1). The positive control, nocodazole, had an IC50 of 2.22 μM for valid neuron count, an IC50 of 0.097 μM for mean neurite average length, and an IC50 of 0.0997 μM for neurite total length per neuron. The negative control, chlorpromazine, had an IC50 of 7.99 μM for valid neuron count, an IC50 of 9.022 μM for mean neurite average length, and an IC50 of 13.8 μM for neurite total length per neuron. Nocodazole was positive for substantially effecting neurite outgrowth while nominally effecting cell viability. Chlorpromazine’s effect on neurite outgrowth was not independent of its effect on cell viability (Table 5). 31e had nominal effects (>100 μM) on all three end points when tested at a top concentration of 100 μM.
    Table 5. Results for Valid Neuron Count, Mean Neurite Average Length, and Neurite Total Length per Neuron
    compdtop concn tested (μM)valid neuron count, IC50 (μM)mean neurite avg length, IC50 (μM)neurite total length per neuron, IC50 (μM)
    nocodazole12.220.0970.0997
    chlorpromazine1007.999.02213.8
    31e100>100>100>100
    The obtained results clearly demonstrate a wide difference (>100-fold) between active concentration of compound 31e and concentration needed to exert a toxic effect. This renders compound 31e suitable for further in vivo investigations.

    Plasma and Brain Levels of 31e

    Pharmacokinetic analysis of the most potent DAT inhibitor 31e was performed by Evotec (Hamburg, Germany) in Sprague-Dawley rats after single intraperitoneal administration at 7.5 mg/kg. In parallel, a brain penetration assessment was performed on three satellite groups. The results are summarized in Table 6.
    Table 6. Plasma and Brain Levels of 31e in Sprague-Dawley Rats after a Single Intraperitoneal Administration of 7.5 mg/kg
     concentration of 31e (nM)
    time (h)plasmaSDbrainSD
    12203193803131
    31211712409223
    789.628.144.325.1
    1023.817.1BLQa
    a

    BLQ: below level of quantification.

    As shown in Table 6, low μM levels of 31e were reached in plasma after 1 and 3 h, which rapidly decreased thereafter. In comparison, as shown previously, ∼3.9 μg/mL of R-modafinil was detected in plasma 1 h after intraperitoneal administration (10 mg/kg body weight) in male Sprague-Dawley rats.(33) Furthermore, the half-life of 31e was determined to be 1.6 ± 0.4 h and was longer as previously shown for R-modafinil (t1/2 = 0.4 ± 0.2 h) and for 6 (t1/2 = 0.9 h).(33) Total drug exposure over time, represented as AUC(0-inf), was determined to be 5843 ± 1439 and was higher than that of R-modafinil (AUC(0-inf) = 1175 ± 1803) but lower than that of 6 (AUC(0-inf) = 13,519).(33) There are several possible explanations for being so. First, the administered dose of 31e was 7.5 mg/kg body weight, i.e., 25% lower than dose for R-modafinil and 6. Second, while R-modafinil and 6 were dissolved in DMSO/Tween 80/saline (10:15:75), 31e was dissolved using a DMSO-free formulation (40% Kolliphor EL in water). The necessity of DMSO-free formulations of hydrophobic substances is due to the recent findings that even small amounts of DMSO may modulate CNS function in vitro, in vivo, and ex vivo.(36,37) In the brain, 31e reached concentration of 803 ± 103 nM at 1 h, 409 ± 223 nM at 3 h, and 44.3 ± 25.1 nM at 7 h. A single intraperitoneal administration of 7.5 mg/kg body weight of 31e is thus sufficient to reach a level in the brain that is somewhat above the IC50 for DAT but far below the IC50 for NET. This compound can thus be expected to exert its desired modafinil-like biological effects in vivo. Other pharmacokinetic parameters are available in Supporting Information.

    In Vivo Brain Microdialysis

    In order to further evaluate drug induced changes in extracellular dopamine levels, i.e., to further estimate drug efficacy in vivo, 31e was administered in two doses (1 and 10 mg/kg bodyweight) intraperitoneally into free moving male Sprague-Dawley rats and dopamine levels were measured in the nucleus accumbens (NAcb). NAcb extracellular DA levels were stable 1 h prior first drug injection [time effect, F(2,34) = 1.650, P = 0.207] and did not differ between the two treatment groups [treatment effect, F(1,17) = 0.971, P = 0.338; treatment × time interaction, F(2,34) = 0.767, P = 0.473)] reaching an average concentration of 3.5 ± 0.27 fmol/5 μL microdialysate. Perfusion with aCSF containing 100 mM KCl caused a pronounced increase in extracellular DA levels in the NAcb as compared with basaline and pre-KCl conditions (KCl effect, F(2,34) = 19.241, P < 0.001; treatment effect, F(1,17) = 0.538, P = 0.473; treatment × KCl interaction, F(2,34) = 0.475, P = 0.626; Figure 8A) indicating functionality of the microdialysis system in each animal. Post-test analysis revealed that while the low dose of 31e (1 mg/kg ip) did not significantly affect extracellular DA levels, the higher dose of 31e (10 mg/kg ip) increased DA concentrations in NAcb microdialysates that peaked at approximately 20% above baseline values 50 min after injection (Figure 8B).

    Conclusion

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    In the current study, a novel series of dopamine reuptake inhibitors based on the modafinil scaffold has been synthesized. Replacement of the carboxamide group of modafinil with a series of substituted and unsubstituted thiazoles and additional modifications in terms of introduction of substitutions on both para-positions of the phenyl rings yielded analogues with somewhat improved activity and nevertheless higher selectivity (DAT vs NET and SERT) compared to modafinil and its R-enantiomer. Observations derived from SAR analysis further indicate that (i) the sulfoxide moiety is important for the activity on DAT and (ii) extension of the bridge to the sulfoxide by exchanging the methylene with an ethylene group significantly decreases activity on DAT. Interestingly, introduction of an additional chiral center led to the discovery of most potent new racemic compound 24i, with an IC50 of 1.85 μM on DAT. Upon purification and testing of individual stereoisomers, analogue 31e was identified as a selective DAT inhibitor with submicromolar activity (IC50 = 0.65 ± 0.07 μM). The absolute configuration of 31e was attributed by means of single crystal X-ray diffraction analysis and was determined to have S configuration on both the chiral C and S atom. The strong correlation of activity on DAT, SERT, and NET with the absolute configuration was confirmed by showing the identical trend in additional six quadruples of stereoisomers. Docking studies of the four individual stereoisomers 31c–f and the inactivity of a derivate with a fluorenyl instead of the diphenylmethyl moiety (17) demonstrate the importance of the two phenyl rings to adopt a nonplanar conformation in the binding pocket. The strong differences in activity and selectivity of the four stereoisomers strongly indicate that further fine-tuning of the asymmetric substituents on the phenyl rings of enantiopure thiazole-based modafinil analogues is the way to go and should enable increasing the DAT activity without simultaneously enhancing activity on NET and SERT to the same extent. On the other hand, this SAR could allow the design of compounds with dual target profile that inhibit both DAT and SERT, as observed for 43d. This could benefit aged people suffering from both cognitive decline and depression. Obviously, even when considering only chemically similar derivatives, there is still a huge chemical space left to be explored, such as combinations of different substituents on both phenyl rings. In the end, asymmetric synthesis strategies that avoid chiral separation by HPLC will have to be developed, as shown for the dual serotonin–norepinephrine reuptake inhibitor (+)-synosutine,(38) to enable successful scale up.
    The most active compound from this series 31e was selected for further characterization. In silico predictions indicated no significant effect on the hERG channel, and in vitro studies have showed that 31e does not cause early after depolarizations (EADs) or changes in action potential duration or shape. In addition, superfusion experiments clearly demonstrated that 31e does not induce reversed transport of dopamine, which is characteristic for amphetamine-like dopamine reuptake inhibitors. 31e showed nominal effects (>100 μM) on all three end points when tested at a top concentration of 100 μM in neurite outgrowth assay indicating a very wide range between activity and neurotoxicity effects to be more than 100-fold. This rendered 31e suitable for further in vivo investigations. A pharmacokinetic study demonstrated that 31e reaches necessary levels in the brain to exert its effect on DAT, while the in vivo microdialysis study demonstrated efficacy of 31e to elevate dopamine levels within nucleus accumbens of freely moving rats.

    Experimental Procedures

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To

    Synthesis

    Reaction conditions and yields were not systematically optimized. Anhydrous solvents were purchased from Sigma-Aldrich and were used as such without further purification. All other chemicals and reagents were purchased from Sigma-Aldrich, TCI Europe/Germany, Synthonix, Acros Organics, Activate Scientific, Fluorochem, Enamine, and Alfa Aesar.
    1H and 13C NMR spectra were recorded on a Bruker Avance 500 NMR spectrometer (UltraShield) using a 5 mm switchable probe (PA BBO 500SB BBF-H-D-05-Z, 1H, BB = 19F and 31P–15N) with z axis gradients and automatic tuning and matching accessory (Bruker BioSpin). The resonance frequency for 1H NMR was 500.13 MHz and for 13C NMR 125.75 MHz. All measurements were performed for a solution in fully deuterated chloroform or DMSO at 298 K. Standard 1D and gradient-enhanced (ge) 2D experiments, like double quantum filtered (DQF) COSY, NOESY, HSQC, and HMBC, were used as supplied by the manufacturer. Chemical shifts are referenced internally to the residual, nondeuterated solvent signal for chloroform 1H (δ = 7.26 ppm) or DMSO 1H (δ = 2.50 ppm) and to the carbon signal of the solvent for chloroform 13C (δ = 77.00 ppm) or DMSO 13C (δ = 39.57 ppm).
    For compound 24d, NMR spectra were recorded on a Bruker Avance III 400 NMR spectrometer (UltraShield) using a 5 mm switchable probe (BBFOPLUS, BB/19F, 1H/D) with z axis gradients and automatic tuning and matching accessory (Bruker BioSpin). The resonance frequency for 1H NMR was 400.23 MHz and for 13C NMR 100.64 MHz. All measurements were performed for a solution in fully deuterated chloroform or methanol at 298 K. Standard 1D and gradient-enhanced (ge) 2D experiments, like double quantum filtered (DQF) COSY, NOESY, HSQC, and HMBC, were used as supplied by the manufacturer. Chemical shifts are referenced internally to the residual, nondeuterated solvent signal for chloroform 1H (δ 7.26 ppm) or methanol 1H (δ 3.31 ppm) and to the carbon signal of the solvent for chloroform 13C (δ 77.00 ppm) or methanol 13C (δ 49.00 ppm).
    HRESIMS spectra were obtained on either a maXis HD or a maXis UHR ESI-Qq-TOF mass spectrometer (Bruker Daltonics, Bremen, Germany). Samples were dissolved to 20 μg/mL in either MeOH or ACN/MeOH/H2O 99:99:2 (v/v/v) and directly infused into the ESI source with a syringe pump. The ESI ion source was operated as follows: capillary voltage, 0.9–4.5 kV (individually optimized); nebulizer, 0.4 bar (N2); dry gas flow, 4 L/min (N2); and dry temperature, 180 or 200 °C. Mass spectra were recorded in the range of m/z 50–1550 in the positive-ion mode. The sum formulas were determined using Bruker Compass DataAnalysis based on the mass accuracy (Δm/z ≤ 2 ppm) and isotopic pattern matching (SmartFormula algorithm).
    The purity of the compounds was determined by HPLC either on an UltiMate 3000 series system equipped with VWD detector (Dionex/Thermo Fisher Scientific, Germering, Germany) or on a LC-2010A HT liquid chromatograph device (Shimadzu Corporation, Tokyo, Japan). Separation was carried out on an Acclaim 120 C18, 2.1 mm × 150 mm, 3 μm HPLC column (Thermo Fisher Scientific) using LC–MS-grade water and acetonitrile as mobile phases A and B, respectively. The sample components were separated and eluted with a linear gradient from 10% to 90% B in 25 min followed by an isocratic column cleaning and re-equilibration step. The flow rate was 0.2 mL/min, and the column oven temperature was set to 25 °C. The purity was determined from the UV chromatogram (254 nm) as the ratio of the peak area of the compound to the total peak area (i.e., the sum of the areas of all peaks that were not present in the solvent blank). On the basis of the HPLC data, all final compounds are ≥95% pure. Melting points were measured on Leica Galen III apparatus (Leica Biosystems, Germany).

    [(Diphenylmethyl)sulfanyl]methanimideamide (9)

    Diphenylmethanol (7) (30.9 g, 168 mmol) and thiourea (8) (14.7 g, 194 mmol) were mixed in a 1 L three-neck round bottomed flask and dissolved in 150 mL of MeOH. The reaction mixture was refluxed for 0.5 h, then 48% HBr (87.4 mL, 772 mmol) was added dropwise over 1 h, followed by stirring under reflux for an additional 2.5 h. After cooling to room temperature, MeOH was removed in vacuum. A pale-yellow product was obtained and suspended in 100 mL of DCM under stirring for 0.5 h at room temperature. The product was filtered and washed with cold DCM. The solid residue was suspended in 100 mL of water and stirred for 0.5 h at room temperature. Finally, the product was filtered under reduced pressure, washed with cold water, and dried under high vacuum to give 38.4 g of a white, powdered solid (yield 71%).

    4-[(Benzhydrylthio)methyl]thiazole (11a)

    To a suspension of thiouronium salt 9 (1.9 g, 5.6 mmol) in MeOH were added solid K2CO3 (5 equiv, 4.06 g) and 4-(chloromethyl)thiazole (1.0 g, 5.88 mmol) in portions. The reaction mixture was stirred at room temperature overnight. The MeOH was evaporated and the residual product was extracted with EtOAc and dried under reduced pressure to give 1.46 g of 11a (yield 84%).

    4-[(Benzhydrylthio)methyl]-2-(thiophen-2-yl)thiazole (11b)

    To a suspension of thiouronium salt 9 (1.6 g, 5.0 mmol) in MeOH were added solid K2CO3 (5 equiv, 3.45 g) and 4-(chloromethyl)-2-(thiophen-2-yl)-1,3-thiazole (1.08 g, 5.0 mmol) in portions. The reaction mixture was stirred at room temperature overnight. The MeOH was evaporated and the residual product was extracted with EtOAc and purified by flash chromatography on silica gel (5% MeOH in DCM) to give 1.24 g of solid 11b (yield 65%).

    4-[(Benzhydrylthio)methyl]-2,5-dimethylthiazole (11c)

    To a suspension of thiouronium salt 9 (1.7 g, 6.2 mmol) in MeOH were added solid K2CO3 (5 equiv, 4.28 g) and 4-(chloromethyl)-2,5-dimethylthiazole (1.0 g, 6.2 mmol) in portions. The reaction mixture was stirred at room temperature overnight. The MeOH was evaporated and the residual product was extracted with EtOAc and dried under reduced pressure to give 1.0 g of 11c (yield 49%).

    4-[(Benzhydrylthio)methyl]-2-isopropylthiazole (11d)

    To a suspension of thiouronium salt 9 (1.84 g, 5.7 mmol) in MeOH were added solid K2CO3 (5 equiv, 3.94 g) and 4-(chloromethyl)-2-isopropylthiazole (1.0 g, 5.7 mmol) in portions. The reaction mixture was stirred at room temperature overnight. The MeOH was evaporated and the residual product was extracted with EtOAc and purified by flash chromatography on silica gel (hexane/EtOAc, 9:1) to give 1.4 g of solid crystalline 11d (yield 72%).

    4-[(Benzhydrylthio)methyl]-2-ethylthiazole (11e)

    To a suspension of thiouronium salt 9 (2.0 g, 6.2 mmol) in MeOH were added solid K2CO3 (5 equiv, 3.4 g) and 4-(chloromethyl)-2-ethylthiazole (1.0 g, 6.2 mmol) in portions. The reaction mixture was stirred at room temperature overnight. The MeOH was evaporated and the residual product was extracted with EtOAc and dried under reduced pressure to give 1.46 g of solid 11e (yield 74%).

    4-[(Benzhydrylthio)methyl]-2-propylthiazole (11f)

    To a suspension of thiouronium salt 9 (1.8 g, 5.8 mmol) in MeOH were added solid K2CO3 (5 equiv, 3.1 g) and 4-(chloromethyl)-2-propylthiazole (1.0 g, 5.8 mmol) in portions. The reaction mixture was stirred at room temperature overnight. The MeOH was evaporated and the residual product was extracted with EtOAc and dried under reduced pressure to give 1.0 g of solid 11f (yield 51%).

    4-[(Benzhydrylthio)methyl]-2-butylthiazole (11g)

    To a suspension of thiouronium salt 9 (2.5 g, 7.9 mmol) in MeOH were added solid K2CO3 (5 equiv, 5.5 g) and 2-butyl-4-(chloromethyl)thiazole (1.5 g, 7.9 mmol) in portions. The reaction mixture was stirred at room temperature overnight. The MeOH was evaporated and the residual product was extracted with EtOAc and purified by flash chromatography on silica gel (5% MeOH in DCM) to give 2.7 g of solid product 11g (yield 98%).

    4-[2-(Benzhydrylthio)ethyl]-2-methylthiazole (11h)

    To a suspension of thiouronium salt 9 (4.0 g, 12.4 mmol) in MeOH were added solid K2CO3 (5 equiv, 8.6 g) and 4-(chloroethyl)-2-methylthiazole (2.0 g, 12.4 mmol) in portions. The reaction mixture was stirred at room temperature overnight. The MeOH was evaporated and the residual product was extracted with EtOAc and dried under reduced pressure to give 3.9 g of solid 11h (yield 98%).

    4-[(Benzhydrylthio)methyl]-2-chlorothiazole (11i)

    To a suspension of thiouronium salt 9 (0.96 g, 2.9 mmol) in MeOH were added solid K2CO3 (5 equiv, 2.0 g) and 2-chloro-4-(chloromethyl)thiazole (0.5 g, 2.9 mmol) in portions. The reaction mixture was stirred at room temperature overnight. The MeOH was evaporated and the residual product was extracted with EtOAc and dried under reduced pressure to give 0.9 g of solid 11i (yield 91%).

    4-[(Benzhydrylthio)methyl]-2-methylthiazole (11j)

    Synthesis procedure as previously reported.(31) Ret. time 24.5 min, purity 99.6%. HRESIMS m/z 334.0694 [M + Na]+ (calcd for C18H17NNaS2+, 334.0695, Δ = 0.1 ppm). 1H NMR (500 MHz, CDCl3) δ = 7.41–7.22 (m, 10H), 6.78 (s, 1H), 5.16 (s, 1H), 3.70 (s, 2H), 2.74 (s, 3H); 13C NMR (125.75 MHz, CDCl3) δ = 166.8 (C), 151.7 (C), 140.8 (C), 128.5 (4CH), 128.4 (4CH), 127.2 (2CH), 115.0 (CH), 53.9 (CH), 30.6 (CH2), 18.9 (CH3).

    2-[(Benzhydrylthio)methyl]-4,5-dimethylthiazole (11k)

    To a suspension of thiouronium salt 9 (3.23 g, 10.0 mmol) in MeOH were added solid K2CO3 (5 equiv, 6.9 g) and 2-(chloromethyl)-4,5-dimethylthiazole (1.6 g, 10.0 mmol) in portions. The reaction mixture was stirred at room temperature overnight. The MeOH was evaporated and the residual product was extracted with EtOAc and purified by flash chromatography on silica gel (5% MeOH in DCM) to give 1.0 g of solid 11k (yield 31%).

    2-[(Benzhydrylthio)methyl]-5-methylthiazole (11l)

    To a suspension of thiouronium salt 9 (2.18 g, 6.8 mmol) in MeOH were added solid K2CO3 (5 equiv, 4.7 g) and 2-(chloromethyl)-5-methylthiazole (1.0 g, 6.8 mmol) in portions. The reaction mixture was stirred at room temperature overnight. The MeOH was evaporated and the residual product was extracted with EtOAc and purified by flash chromatography on silica gel (5% MeOH in DCM) to give 1.1 g of solid product 11l (yield 49%).

    5-[(Benzhydrylthio)methyl]-2-methylthiazole (11m)

    To a suspension of thiouronium salt 9 (2.2 g, 6.8 mmol) in MeOH were added solid K2CO3 (5 equiv, 4.7 g) and 5-(chloromethyl)-2-methylthiazole (1.0 g, 6.8 mmol) in portions. The reaction mixture was stirred at room temperature overnight. The MeOH was evaporated and the residual product was extracted with EtOAc and purified by flash chromatography on silica gel (2.5% MeOH in DCM) to give 1.15 g of solid product 11m (yield 54%).

    5-[(Benzhydrylthio)methyl]-2-chlorothiazole (11n)

    To a suspension of thiouronium salt 9 (3.8 g, 11.9 mmol) in MeOH were added solid K2CO3 (5 equiv, 8.21 g) and 2-chloro-5-(chloromethyl)thiazole (2.0 g, 11.9 mmol) in portions. The reaction mixture was stirred at room temperature overnight. The MeOH was evaporated and the residual product was extracted with EtOAc and dried under reduced pressure to give 2.2 g of solid white 11n (yield 56%).

    5-[(Benzhydrylthio)methyl]-2-(tert-butyl)thiazole (11o)

    To a suspension of thiouronium salt 9 (1.7 g, 5.3 mmol) in MeOH were added solid K2CO3 (5 equiv, 3.6 g) and 2-(tert-butyl)-4-(chloromethyl)thiazole (1.0 g, 5.3 mmol) in portions. The reaction mixture was stirred at room temperature overnight. The MeOH was evaporated and the residual products were extracted with EtOAc and concentrated under reduced pressure to give 1.6 g of solid 11o (yield 86%).

    5-[(Benzhydrylthio)methyl]-2-(1-adamantyl)-1,3-thiazole (11p)

    To a suspension of thiouronium salt 9 (2g, 6.2 mmol) in dioxane (20 mL) and water (20 mL) were added aqueous NaOH (2.5 g in 10 mL of water) and 2-(1-adamantyl)-5-(chloromethyl)-1,3-thiazole (1.65 g, 6.2 mmol) in portions. The reaction mixture was stirred at 90 °C for 2 h. The next day, the dioxane was evaporated, water was added, the reaction product was extracted with CH2Cl2 and purified by flash chromatography (CH2Cl2/petroleum ether, 3:5) to give 2.65 g of the compound 11p (yield 99%).

    5-[(Benzhydrylthio)methyl]-2-methoxythiazole (11q)

    To a suspension of thiouronium salt 9 (3.8 g, 11.9 mmol) in MeOH were added solid K2CO3 (5 equiv, 8.2 g) and 5-(chloromethyl)-2-methoxythiazole (2.0 g, 11.9 mmol) in portions. The reaction mixture was stirred at room temperature overnight. The MeOH was evaporated and the residual product was extracted with EtOAc and dried under reduced pressure to give 2.2 g of white solid 11q (yield 56%).

    5-[(Benzhydrylthio)methyl]-4-methylthiazole (11r)

    To a suspension of thiouronium salt 9 (1.6 g, 4.9 mmol) in MeOH were added solid K2CO3 (5 equiv, 3.4 g) and 5-(chloromethyl)-4-methylthiazole (0.73 g, 4.9 mmol) in portions. The reaction mixture was stirred at room temperature overnight. The MeOH was evaporated and the residual product was extracted with EtOAc and dried under reduced pressure to give 1.53 g of solid 11r (yield 99%).

    5-[(Benzhydrylthio)methyl]-2,4-dimethylthiazole (11s)

    To a suspension of thiouronium salt 9 (1.52 g, 4.7 mmol) in MeOH were added solid K2CO3 (5 equiv, 3.45 g) and 5-(chloromethyl)-2,4-dimethylthiazole (0.76 g, 4.7 mmol) in portions. The reaction mixture was stirred at room temperature overnight. The MeOH was evaporated and the residual product was extracted with EtOAc and purified by flash chromatography on silica gel (hexane/EtOAc, 1:1) to give 1.4 g of solid 11s (yield 43%).

    4-[(Benzhydrylsulfinyl)methyl]thiazole (12a)

    30% H2O2 (0.56 mL) was added to the solution of 11a (1.46 g, 4.9 mmol) in glacial acetic acid (20 mL). The reaction mixture was stirred at room temperature during 24 h. Then, the reaction mixture was neutralized with cold 5% sodium bicarbonate solution. The reaction product was extracted (3 × 50 mL) with EtOAc and dried over anhydrous Na2SO4. The organic solution was concentrated under reduced pressure and the residue purified by flash column chromatography (5% MeOH in DCM). The product was dried in high vacuum to give 1.1 g of 12a as a white solid (yield 71%). Mp 123–126 °C. Ret. time 4.24 min, purity 96.5%. HRESIMS m/z 336.0487 [M + Na]+ (calcd for C17H15NNaOS2+, 336.0847, Δ = 0.0 ppm). 1H NMR (500 MHz, CDCl3) δ = 8.85 (s, 1H), 7.52–7.47 (m, 4H), 7.42–7.23 (m, 7H), 5.06 (s, 1H), 4.11 (d, J = 13.5 Hz, 1H), 3.90 (d, J = 13.5 Hz, 1H); 13C NMR (125.75 MHz, CDCl3) δ = 153.1 (CH), 146.1 (C), 135.7 (C), 134.2 (C), 129.7 (2CH), 129.2 (2CH), 128.9 (2CH), 128.7 (2CH), 128.3 (2CH), 119.2 (CH), 70.2 (CH), 51.1 (CH2).

    4-[(Benzhydrylsulfinyl)methyl]-2-(thiophen-2-yl)thiazole (12b)

    30% H2O2 (0.45 mL) was added to the solution of 11b (1.24 g, 3.3 mmol) in glacial acetic acid (20 mL). The reaction mixture was stirred at room temperature during 24 h. Then, the reaction mixture was neutralized with cold 5% sodium bicarbonate solution. The reaction product was extracted (3 × 50 mL) with EtOAc and dried over anhydrous Na2SO4. The organic solution was concentrated under reduced pressure and the residue purified by flash column chromatography on silica gel (2.5% MeOH in DCM). The product was dried in high vacuum to give 1.2 g of 12b as a white solid (yield 92%). Mp 122–126 °C. Ret. time 22.74 min, purity >99.9%.     2-(Adamantan-1-yl)-5-[(benzhydrylsulfinyl)methyl]thiazole (12p)

    27.6% H2O2 (0.66 mL) was added to the solution of 11p (6.2 mmol, 2.65 g) in glacial acetic acid (20 mL). The reaction mixture was stirred at room temperature during 24 h. The product was dried in high vacuum to give 0.6 g of 12s as a yellow solid (yield 41%). Mp 83–88 °C. Ret. time 18.53 min, purity >99.9%. HRESIMS m/z 364.0804 [M + Na]+ (calcd for C19H19NNaOS2+, 364.0800, Δ = 0.9 ppm). 1H NMR (500 MHz, CDCl3) δ = 7.45–7.33 (m, 10H), 3.97 (d, J = 14.4 Hz, 1H), 3.79 (d, J = 14.4 Hz, 1H), 2.66 (s, 3H), 2.10 (s, 3H); 13C NMR (125.75 MHz, CDCl3) δ = 165.5 (C), 151.5 (C), 135.3 (C), 134.3 (C), 129.4 (2CH-o + 2CH-m), 128.8 (2CH), 128.6 (2CH), 128.5 (CH), 128.4 (CH), 117.9 (C), 70.3 (CH), 47.6 (CH2), 19.2 (CH3), 15.3 (CH3).

    9H-Fluoren-9-yl carbamimidothioate Hydrobromide (14)

    To a vigorously stirred mixture of thiourea (1.65 g, 21.7 mmol), 48% HBr (15 mL), and water (10 mL) at 70–75 °C was added 9-hydroxyfluorene (3 g, 16.5 mmol) in small portions, followed by an additional amount of water (30 mL). The reaction mixture was then heated to 100–105 °C, maintained for another 1 h, and cooled to room temperature. The precipitate was filtered, washed with water, suspended in CH2Cl2, and filtered again to give 4.96 g (yield 94%) of the corresponding thiouronium salt that was used in the next step without further purification.

    2-{[(9H-Fluoren-9-yl)thio]methyl}thiazole (16)

    To a suspension of thiouronium salt 14 (2 g, 6.2 mmol) in dioxane (20 mL) was added aqueous NaOH (2.5 g in 20 mL of water) and 2-(chloromethyl)thiazole (15) (0.83 g, 6.2 mmol) in portions. The reaction mixture was stirred at 70 °C for 5 h. The next day, the dioxane was evaporated, and the reaction product was extracted with CH2Cl2 and purified by flash chromatography (CH2Cl2) to give 1.65 g of compound with minor byproduct (which was removed after oxidation).

    2-{[(9H-Fluoren-9-yl)sulfinyl]methyl}thiazole (17)

    27.6% H2O2 (0.5 mL) was added to the solution of 16 (5.59 mmol, 1.65 g) in glacial acetic acid (20 mL). The reaction mixture was stirred at room temperature during 24 h. The solvent was evaporated in vacuum until dryness. The residue was diluted with water, extracted with CH2Cl2, dried, and purified by column chromatography (hexane, hexane/CH2Cl2 1:1, CH2Cl2, CH2Cl2/EtOAc 1:1) to yield 1.17 g (yield 67%) of final product 17 as orange crystals. Mp 107–109 °C. Ret. time 17.20 min, purity >98.6% HRESIMS m/z 334.0334 [M + Na]+ (calcd for C17H13NNaOS2+, 334.0331, Δ = 0.9 ppm). δ = 8.03 (d, J = 7.6 Hz, 1H), 7.85 (d, J = 7.6 Hz, 1H), 7.81 (d, J = 7.6 Hz, 1H), 7.72 (d, J = 3.2 Hz, 1H), 7.63 (d, J = 7.5 Hz, 1H), 7.55 (t, J = 7.5 Hz, 1H), 7.50–7.43 (m, 2H), 7.36 (t, J = 7.5 Hz, 1H), 7.27 (s, 1H), 5.41 (s, 1H), 3.40 (d, J = 13.8 Hz, 1H), 3.35 (d, J = 13.8 Hz, 1H); 13C NMR (125.75 MHz, CDCl3) δ = 158.9 (C), 143.2 (CH), 141.7 (C), 141.2 (C), 136.4 (C), 135.6 (C), 129.5 (CH), 129.4 (CH), 128.0 (2CH), 126.7 (CH), 125.7 (CH), 121.0 (CH), 120.9 (CH), 120.5 (CH), 65.6 (CH), 48.4 (CH2).

    S-[(Thiazol-4-yl)methyl] Ethanethioate (20a)

    To a suspension of 4-(chloromethyl)thiazole hydrochloride (18a) (5.1 g, 30 mmol), K2CO3 (8.3 g), and NaI (0.2 g) in acetone (60 mL), thioacetic acid (19) (2.67 g, 35 mmol) was added dropwise, and the resulting mixture was stirred at 35–40 °C under argon for 3 h. The reaction mixture was diluted with water, extracted with CH2Cl2, filtered with charcoal and the product purified by flash column chromatography (CH2Cl2) to give 5.1 g of the 20a as a yellow oil (yield 98%).

    S-[(Thiazol-2-yl)methyl] Ethanethioate (20b)

    To a suspension of 2-(chloromethyl)thiazole hydrochloride (18b) (5.02 g, 29 mmol), K2CO3 (8.2 g), and NaI (0.2 g) in acetone (60 mL), thioacetic acid (19) (2.55 g, 33 mmol) was added dropwise, and the resulting mixture was stirred at 35–40 °C under argon for 3 h. The reaction mixture was diluted with water, extracted with CH2Cl2, filtered with charcoal and the product purified by flash column chromatography (CH2Cl2) to give 4.7 g of 20b as a yellow oil (yield 93%).

    S-[(Thiazol-5-yl)methyl] Ethanethioate (20c)

    A mixture of 5-(chloromethyl)-1,3-thiazole hydrochloride (18c) (5.0 g, 29.4 mmol), thioacetic acid (19) (2.65 g, 32.11 mmol), potassium carbonate (10.5 g, 76 mmol), and acetone (100 mL) was stirred overnight at rt. The precipitate was filtered off and washed with acetone. The filtrate and rinse were combined and evaporated in vacuum to minimal volume. Water (50 mL) and DCM (50 mL) were added to the residue, and the mixture was stirred for 15 min. The organic layer was washed with water, dried over Na2SO4, and the solvent was evaporated in vacuum. The resulting brownish oil was purified by flash chromatography on silica gel (DCM) to give 3.78 g of 20c as a yellowish oil (yield 74%).

    S-[(2-Methylthiazol-4-yl)methyl] Ethanethioate (20d)

    A mixture of 4-(chloromethyl)-2-methyl-1,3-thiazole hydrochloride (18d) (8.3 g, 45.1 mmol), thioacetic acid (19) (4.0 g, 52.6 mmol), potassium carbonate (16.2 g, 117 mmol), and acetone (160 mL) was stirred overnight at rt. The precipitate was filtered off and washed with acetone. The filtrate and rinse were combined and evaporated in vacuum to minimal volume. The resulting brownish oil was purified by flash chromatography on silica gel (DCM) to give 8.07 g of 20d as a yellowish oil (yield 95%).

    S-[(2-Cyclopropylthiazol-4-yl)methyl] Ethanethioate (20e)

    A solution of 1,3-dichloropropan-2-one (6.28 g, 49 mmol) and cyclopropanecarbothioamide (4.99 g, 49 mmol) in i-PrOH (70 mL) was heated under argon for 5.5 h and then concentrated under reduced pressure. The residue was dissolved in acetone (60 mL), and Cs2CO3 (8.0 g), NaI (0.4 g), and thioacetic acid (4.36 g, 0.057 mol) were added. The resulting mixture was stirred at 35–40 °C under argon for 3 h, diluted with water, and extracted with CH2Cl2. The extract was concentrated and purified by flash column chromatography (petroleum ether/EtOAc, 8:1) to give 5.5 g of 20e as a yellow oil (yield 52%).

    General Procedure for Obtaining 21a–e Intermediates

    20a–e were dissolved in EtOH, and an amount of 2 equiv of NaOH dissolved in 2–5 mL of H2O was added. The reaction mixture was refluxed for 2 h and then extracted with EtOAc upon neutralization to pH 7 with conc HCL. The extract was dried over anhydrous Na2SO4, filtered, concentrated, and used as such immediately in further steps.

    4-({[Bis(4-chlorophenyl)methyl)thio]methyl}thiazole (23a)

    1.1 g (4.3 mmol) of bis(4-chlorophenyl)methanol and 0.57 g (4.3 mmol) of thiazol-4-ylmethanethiol were dissolved in glacial acetic acid. An amount of 1.1 equiv (1.2 mL, 4.8 mmol) of BF3·Et2O was added, and the reaction mixture was left under stirring overnight at room temperature. The reaction mixture was then poured over ice, a small amount of water was added, and the acetic acid was neutralized with addition of solid NaHCO3. The product was then extracted (3×) with 50 mL of EtOAc. Organic layers were collected, combined, dried over anhydrous Na2SO4, filtered, and concentrated under reduced pressure. The crude product was then purified by flash column chromatography on silica gel (2.5% MeOH in DCM) affording 1.3 g of 23a as a yellow oily product (yield 83%).

    2-Cyclopropyl-4-({[bis(4-chlorophenyl)methyl]thio}methyl)thiazole (23b)

    0.88 g (3.5 mmol) of bis(4-chlorophenyl)methanol and 0.59 g (3.5 mmol) of (2-cyclopropylthiazol-4-yl)methanethiol were dissolved in glacial acetic acid. An amount of 1.1 equiv (0.9 mL, 3.85 mmol) of BF3·Et2O was added, and the reaction mixture was left under stirring overnight at room temperature. The reaction mixture was then poured over ice, a small amount of water was added, and the acetic acid was neutralized with addition of solid NaHCO3. The product was then extracted (3×) with 50 mL of EtOAc. Organic layers were collected, combined, dried over anhydrous Na2SO4, filtered, and concentrated under reduced pressure. The crude product was then purified by flash column chromatography on silica gel (2.5% MeOH in DCM) affording 0.38 g of 23b as a yellow oil (yield 27%).

    2-Cyclopropyl-4-({[bis(4-methylphenyl)methyl]thio}methyl)thiazole (23c)

    0.74 g (3.5 mmol) of di-p-tolylmethanol and 0.59 g (3.5 mmol) of (2-cyclopropylthiazol-4-yl)methanethiol were dissolved in glacial acetic acid. An amount of 1.1 equiv (0.9 mL, 3.85 mmol) of BF3·Et2O was added, and the reaction mixture was left under stirring overnight at room temperature. The reaction mixture was then poured over ice, a small amount of water was added, and the acetic acid was neutralized with addition of solid NaHCO3. The product was then extracted (3×) with 50 mL of EtOAc. Organic layers were collected, combined, dried over anhydrous Na2SO4, filtered, and concentrated under reduced pressure. The crude product was then purified by flash column chromatography on silica gel (petroleum ether/EtOAc: 2/1) affording 0.3 g of 23c as an oily product (yield 23%).

    5-({[Bis(4-methoxyphenyl)methyl]thio}methyl)thiazole (23d)

    0.75 g (3.0 mmol) of bis(4-methoxyphenyl)methanol and 0.39 g (3.0 mmol) of thiazol-5-ylmethanethiol were dissolved in glacial acetic acid. An amount of 1.1 equiv (0.86 mL, 3.3 mmol) of BF3·Et2O was added, and the reaction mixture was left under stirring overnight at room temperature. The reaction mixture was then poured over ice, a small amount of water was added, and the acetic acid was neutralized with addition of solid NaHCO3. The product was then extracted (3×) with 50 mL of EtOAc. Organic layers were collected, combined, dried over anhydrous Na2SO4, filtered, and concentrated under reduced pressure. The crude product was then purified by flash column chromatography on silica gel (2.5% MeOH in DCM) affording 0.49 g of 23d as an oily product (yield 45%).

    4-({[Bis(4-fluorophenyl)methyl]thio}methyl)thiazole (23e)

    2.0 g (6.0 mmol) of bis(4-fluorophenyl)methanol and 0.78 g (6.0 mmol) of thiazol-4-ylmethanethiol were dissolved in glacial acetic acid. An amount of 1.1 equiv (1.7 mL, 6.6 mmol) of BF3·Et2O was added, and the reaction mixture was left under stirring overnight at room temperature. The reaction mixture was then poured over ice, a small amount of water was added, and the acetic acid was neutralized with addition of solid NaHCO3. The product was then extracted (3×) with 50 mL of EtOAc. Organic layers were collected, combined, dried over anhydrous Na2SO4, filtered, and concentrated under reduced pressure. The crude product was then purified by flash column chromatography on silica gel (2.5% MeOH in DCM) affording 1.94 g of 23e as an oily product (yield 97%).

    4-({[Bis(4-methylphenyl)methyl]thio}methyl)thiazole (23f)

    0.65 g (3.0 mmol) of di-p-tolylmethanol and 0.4 g (3.0 mmol) of thiazol-4-ylmethanethiol were dissolved in glacial acetic acid. An amount of 1.1 equiv (0.9 mL, 3.3 mmol) of BF3·Et2O was added, and the reaction mixture was left under stirring overnight at room temperature. The reaction mixture was then poured over ice, a small amount of water was added, and the acetic acid was neutralized with addition of solid NaHCO3. The product was then extracted (3×) with 50 mL of EtOAc. Organic layers were collected, combined, dried over anhydrous Na2SO4, filtered, and concentrated under reduced pressure. The crude product was then purified by flash column chromatography on silica gel (2.5% MeOH in DCM) affording 0.26 g of 23f as an oily product (yield 27%).

    4-({[Bis(4-methoxyphenyl)methyl]thio}methyl)-2-cyclopropylthiazole (23g)

    0.52 g (2.1 mmol) of bis(4-methoxyphenyl)methanol and 0.87 g (2.1 mmol) of (2-cyclopropylthiazol-4-yl)methanethiol were dissolved in glacial acetic acid. An amount of 1.1 equiv (0.6 mL, 2.3 mmol) of BF3·Et2O was added, and the reaction mixture was left under stirring overnight at room temperature. The reaction mixture was then poured over ice, a small amount of water was added, and the acetic acid was neutralized with addition of solid NaHCO3. The product was then extracted (3×) with 50 mL of EtOAc. Organic layers were collected, combined, dried over anhydrous Na2SO4, filtered, and concentrated under reduced pressure. The crude product was then purified by flash column chromatography on silica gel (2.5% MeOH in DCM) affording 0.8 g of 23g as an oily product (yield 90%).

    5-({[Bis(4-chlorophenyl)methyl]thio}methyl)thiazole (23h)

    0.85 g (3.4 mmol) of bis(4-chlorophenyl)methanol and 0.44 g (3.4 mmol) of thiazol-5-ylmethanethiol were dissolved in glacial acetic acid. An amount of 1.1 equiv (0.95 mL, 3.7 mmol) of BF3·Et2O was added, and the reaction mixture was left under stirring overnight at room temperature. The reaction mixture was then poured over ice, a small amount of water was added, and the acetic acid was neutralized with addition of solid NaHCO3. The product was then extracted (3×) with 50 mL of EtOAc. Organic layers were collected, combined, dried over anhydrous Na2SO4, filtered, and concentrated under reduced pressure. The crude product was then purified by flash column chromatography on silica gel (2.5% MeOH in DCM) affording 0.6 g of 23.h as an oily product (yield 53%).

    4-({[(4-Bromophenyl)(phenyl)methyl]thio}methyl)thiazole (23i)

    1.4 g (5.3 mmol) of 4-bromobenzhydrol and 0.7 g (5.3 mmol) of thiazol-4-ylmethanethiol were dissolved in glacial acetic acid. An amount of 1.1 equiv (1.5 mL, 5.8 mmol) of BF3·Et2O was added, and the reaction mixture was left under stirring overnight at room temperature. The reaction mixture was then poured over ice, a small amount of water was added, and the acetic acid was neutralized with addition of solid NaHCO3. The product was then extracted (3×) with 50 mL of EtOAc. Organic layers were collected, combined, dried over anhydrous Na2SO4, filtered, and concentrated under reduced pressure. The crude product was then purified by flash column chromatography on silica gel (2.5% MeOH in DCM) affording 1.3 g of 23i as an oily product (yield 64%).

    2-({[Bis(4-chlorophenyl)methyl]thio}methyl)thiazole (23j)

    0.68 g (2.7 mmol) of bis(4-chlorophenyl)methanol and 0.35 g (2.7 mmol) of thiazol-2-ylmethanethiol were dissolved in glacial acetic acid. An amount of 1.1 equiv (0.75 mL, 3.0 mmol) of BF3·Et2O was added, and the reaction mixture was left under stirring overnight at room temperature. The reaction mixture was then poured over ice, a small amount of water was added, and the acetic acid was neutralized with addition of solid NaHCO3. The product was then extracted (3×) with 50 mL of EtOAc. Organic layers were collected, combined, dried over anhydrous Na2SO4, filtered, and concentrated under reduced pressure. The crude product was then purified by flash column chromatography on silica gel (2.5% MeOH in DCM) affording 0.24 g of 23j as an oily product (yield 22%).

    5-({[Bis(4-fluorophenyl)methyl]thio}methyl)thiazole (23k)

    0.65 g (2.9 mmol) of bis(4-fluorophenyl)methanol and 0.38 g (2.9 mmol) of thiazol-5-ylmethanethiol were dissolved in glacial acetic acid. An amount of 1.1 equiv (0.8 mL, 3.2 mmol) of BF3·Et2O was added, and the reaction mixture was left under stirring overnight at room temperature. The reaction mixture was then poured over ice, a small amount of water was added, and the acetic acid was neutralized with addition of solid NaHCO3. The product was then extracted (3×) with 50 mL of EtOAc. Organic layers were collected, combined, dried over anhydrous Na2SO4, filtered, and concentrated under reduced pressure. The crude product was then purified by flash column chromatography on silica gel (2.5% MeOH in DCM) affording 0.5 g of 23k as an oily product (yield 48%).

    5-({[Bis(4-methylphenyl)methyl]thio}methyl)thiazole (23l)

    0.5 g (2.4 mmol) of di-p-tolylmethanol and 0.31 g (2.4 mmol) of thiazol-5-ylmethanethiol were dissolved in glacial acetic acid. An amount of 1.1 equiv (0.7 mL, 2.65 mmol) of BF3·Et2O was added, and the reaction mixture was left under stirring overnight at room temperature. The reaction mixture was then poured over ice, a small amount of water was added, and the acetic acid was neutralized with addition of solid NaHCO3. The product was then extracted (3×) with 50 mL of EtOAc. Organic layers were collected, combined, dried over anhydrous Na2SO4, filtered, and concentrated under reduced pressure. The crude product was then purified by flash column chromatography on silica gel (2.5% MeOH in DCM) affording 0.4 g of 23l as an oily product (yield 50%).

    2-({[Bis(4-methylphenyl)methyl]thio}methyl)thiazole (23m)

    0.6 g (2.9 mmol) of di-p-tolylmethanol and 0.37 g (2.9 mmol) of thiazol-2-ylmethanethiol were dissolved in glacial acetic acid. An amount of 1.1 equiv (0.8 mL, 3.2 mmol) of BF3·Et2O was added, and the reaction mixture was left under stirring overnight at room temperature. The reaction mixture was then poured over ice, a small amount of water was added, and the acetic acid was neutralized with addition of solid NaHCO3. The product was then extracted (3×) with 50 mL of EtOAc. Organic layers were collected, combined, dried over anhydrous Na2SO4, filtered, and concentrated under reduced pressure. The crude product was then purified by flash column chromatography on silica gel (2.5% MeOH in DCM) affording 0.57 g of 23m as an oily product (yield 61%).

    4-({[Bis(4-chlorophenyl)methyl]sulfinyl}methyl)thiazole (24a)

    30% H2O2 (0.43 mL) was added to the solution of 23a (1.37 g, 3.7 mmol) in glacial acetic acid (20 mL). The reaction mixture was stirred at room temperature during 24 h. Then, the reaction mixture was neutralized with cold 5% sodium bicarbonate solution. The reaction product was extracted (3 × 50 mL) with EtOAc and dried over anhydrous Na2SO4. The organic solution was concentrated under reduced pressure and the residue purified by flash column chromatography on silica gel (5% MeOH in DCM). The product was dried in high vacuum to give 0.31 g of 24a as a yellow solid (yield 24%). Mp 114–117 °C. Ret. time 22.45 min, purity 95.4%. HRESIMS m/z 403.9707 [M + Na]+ (calcd for C17H13Cl2NNaOS2+, 403.9708, Δ = 0.2 ppm). 1H NMR (500 MHz, CDCl3) δ = 8.86 (s, 1H), 7.43–7.36 (m, 9H), 5. 07 (s, 1H), 4.10 (d, J = 13.5 Hz, 1H), 3.90 (d, J = 13.6 Hz, 1H); 13C NMR (125.75 MHz, CDCl3) δ = 150.2 (CH), 145.4 (C), 134.7 (C), 134.5 (C), 133.9 (C), 132.0 (C), 131.1 (2CH), 130.3 (2CH), 129.4 (2CH), 128.9 (2CH), 119.6 (CH), 67.6 (CH), 50.7 (CH2).

    4-({[Bis(4-chlorophenyl)methyl]sulfinyl}methyl)-2-cyclopropylthiazole (24b)

    30% H2O2 (0.9 mL) was added to the solution of 23b (0.38 g, 0.9 mmol) in glacial acetic acid (10 mL). The reaction mixture was stirred at room temperature during 24 h. Then, the reaction mixture was neutralized with cold 5% sodium bicarbonate solution. The reaction product was extracted (3 × 50 mL) with EtOAc and dried over anhydrous Na2SO4. The organic solution was concentrated under reduced pressure and the residue purified by flash column chromatography on silica gel (2.5% MeOH in DCM). The product was dried in high vacuum to give 0.26 g of 24b as a transparent oil (yield 65%). Ret. time 25.80 min, purity 98.2%. HRESIMS m/z 444.0021 [M + Na]+ (calcd for C20H17Cl2NNaOS2+, 444.0021, Δ = 0.1 ppm). 1H NMR (500 MHz, CDCl3) δ = 7.42–7.35 (m, 8H), 7.02 (s, 1H), 5.15 (s, 1H), 3.98 (d, J = 13.5 Hz, 1H), 3.76 (d, J = 13.5 Hz, 1H), 2.34 (br s, 1H), 1.25–1.10 (m, 4H); 13C NMR (125.75 MHz, CDCl3) δ = 174.6 (C), 143.5 (C), 134.7 (C), 134.4 (C), 134.3 (C), 131.9, 131.2 (2CH), 130.2 (2CH), 129.3 (2CH), 128.6 (2C), 117.2 (CH), 67.4 (CH), 51.1 (CH2), 14.5 (CH), 11.7 (2CH2).

    4-({[Bis(4-methylphenyl)methyl]sulfinyl}methyl)-2-cyclopropylthiazole (24c)

    30% H2O2 (0.95 mL) was added to the solution of 23c (0.3 g, 0.82 mmol) in glacial acetic acid (20 mL). The reaction mixture was stirred at room temperature during 24 h. Then, the reaction mixture was neutralized with cold 5% sodium bicarbonate solution. The reaction product was extracted (3 × 50 mL) with EtOAc and dried over anhydrous Na2SO4. The organic solution was concentrated under reduced pressure and the residue purified by flash column chromatography on silica gel (5% MeOH in DCM). The product was dried in high vacuum to give 0.14 g of 24c as a yellow oil (yield 45%). Ret. time 24.32 min, purity 98.8%. HRESIMS m/z 404.1114 [M + Na]+ (calcd for C22H23NNaOS2, 404.1113, Δ = 0.2 ppm). 1H (500 MHz, CDCl3) δ = 7.39–7.33 (m, 4H), 7.21–7.15 (m, 4H), 7.00 (br s, 1H), 5.03 (s, 1H), 3.96 (d, J = 13.5 Hz, 1H), 3.73 (d, J = 13.5 Hz, 1H), 2.36–2.27 (m, 7H), 1.18–1.13 (m, 2H), 1.10–1.03 (m, 2H); 13C (125.75 MHz, CDCl3) δ = 173.9 (C), 144.5 (C), 138.0 (CH), 133.1 (C), 131.4 (C), 129.7 (2CH), 129.6 (2CH), 129.3 (2CH), 128.8 (2CH), 116.7 (CH), 69.5 (CH), 51.4 (CH2), 21.1 (2CH3), 14.5 (CH), 11.2 (2CH2).

    5-({[Bis(4-methoxyphenyl)methyl]sulfinyl}methyl)thiazole (24d)

    30% H2O2 (0.16 mL) was added to the solution of 23d (0.49 g, 1.37 mmol) in glacial acetic acid (20 mL). The reaction mixture was stirred at room temperature during 24 h. Then, the reaction mixture was neutralized with cold 5% sodium bicarbonate solution. The reaction product was extracted (3 × 50 mL) with EtOAc and dried over anhydrous Na2SO4. The organic solution was concentrated under reduced pressure and the residue purified by flash column chromatography on silica gel (2.5% MeOH in DCM). The product was dried in high vacuum to give 0.2 g of 24d as a yellow oil (yield 40%). Ret. time 14.94 min, purity 98.5%.
