    4-({[Bis(4-fluorophenyl)methyl]sulfinyl}methyl)thiazole (24e)

    30% H2O2 (0.7 mL) was added to the solution of 23e (1.9 g, 6.0 mmol) in glacial acetic acid (20 mL). The reaction mixture was stirred at room temperature during 24 h. Then, the reaction mixture was neutralized with cold 5% sodium bicarbonate solution. The reaction product was extracted (3 × 50 mL) with EtOAc and dried over anhydrous Na2SO4. The organic solution was concentrated under reduced pressure and the residue purified by flash column chromatography on silica gel (2.5% MeOH in DCM). The product was dried in high vacuum to give 0.38 g of 24e as a white solid (yield 21%). Mp 126–128 °C. Ret. time 18.02 min, purity 97.35%. HRESIMS m/z 372.0304 [M + Na]+ (calcd for C17H13F2NNaOS2+, 372.0299, Δ = 1.4 ppm). 1H NMR (500 MHz, CDCl3) δ = 8.86 (d, J = 1.9 Hz, 1H), 7.49–7.46 (m, 2H), 7.43–7.41 (m, 2H), 7.37 (d, J = 1.9 Hz, 1H), 7.12–7.06 (m, 4H), 5.08 (s, 1H), 4.09 (d, J = 13.6 Hz, 1H), 3.89 (d, J = 13.6 Hz, 1H); 13C NMR (125.75 MHz, CDCl3) δ = 162.8 (d, 1J(13C, 19F) = 246.8 Hz, CF), 162.5 (d, 1J(13C, 19F) = 248.9 Hz, CF), 153.3 (CH), 145.6 (C), 131.5 (d, 3J(13C, 19F) = 8.2 Hz, 2CH), 131.4 (d, 4J(13C,19F) = 3.7 Hz, C), 130.7 (d, 3J(13C, 19F) = 8.1 Hz, 2CH), 129.5 (d, 4J(13C, 19F) = 3.0 Hz, C), 119.5 (CH), 116.2 (d, 2J(13C, 19F) = 21.5 Hz, 2CH), 115.7 (d, 2J(13C, 19F) = 21.2, 2CH), 67.5 (CH), 50.7 (CH2).

    4-({[Bis(4-methylphenyl)methyl]sulfinyl}methyl)thiazole (24f)

    30% H2O2 (0.1 mL) was added to the solution of 23f (0.26 g, 0.8 mmol) in glacial acetic acid (20 mL). The reaction mixture was stirred at room temperature during 24 h. Then, the reaction mixture was neutralized with cold 5% sodium bicarbonate solution. The reaction product was extracted (3 × 50 mL) with EtOAc and dried over anhydrous Na2SO4. The organic solution was concentrated under reduced pressure and the residue purified by flash column chromatography on silica gel (5% MeOH in DCM). The product was dried in high vacuum to give 0.15 g of 24f as a white solid (yield 54%). Mp 117–120 °C. Ret. time 19.88 min, purity 99.1%. HRESIMS m/z 364.0801 [M + Na]+ (calcd for C19H19NNaOS2+, 364.0800, Δ = 0.1 ppm). 1H NMR (500 MHz, CDCl3) δ = 8.84 (s, 1H), 7.38–7.34 (m, 5H), 7.20–7.13 (m, 4H), 4.96 (s, 1H), 4.10 (d, J = 13.3 Hz, 1H), 3.88 (d, J = 13.3 Hz, 1H), 2.34 (s, 3H), 2.32 (s, 3H); 13C NMR (125.75 MHz, CDCl3) δ = 153. 0 (CH), 146.3 (C), 138.1 (C), 138.0 (C), 132.8 (C), 131.4 (C), 129.8 (2CH), 129.4 (2CH), 129.1 (2CH), 128.7 (2CH), 119.1 (CH), 70.1 (CH), 51.2 (CH2), 21.1 (2CH3).

    4-({[Bis(4-methoxyphenyl)methyl]sulfinyl}methyl)-2-cyclopropylthiazole (24g)

    30% H2O2 (0.2 mL) was added to the solution of 23g (0.8 g, 1.9 mmol) in glacial acetic acid (10 mL). The reaction mixture was stirred at room temperature during 24 h. Then, the reaction mixture was neutralized with cold 5% sodium bicarbonate solution. The reaction product was extracted (3 × 50 mL) with EtOAc and dried over anhydrous Na2SO4. The organic solution was concentrated under reduced pressure and the residue purified by flash column chromatography on silica gel (2.5% MeOH in DCM). The product was dried in high vacuum to give 0.09 g of 24g as a yellow oil (yield 11%). Ret. time 23.63 min, purity 98.4%. HRESIMS m/z 436.1010 [M + Na]+ (calcd for C22H23NNaO3S2+, 436.1012, Δ = 0.3 ppm). 1H (500 MHz, CDCl3) δ = 7.41–7.37 (m, 4H), 7.01 (br s, 1H), 6.92–6.90 (m, 4H), 5.03 (s, 1H), 3.96 (d, J = 13.4 Hz, 1H), 3.80 (s, 6H), 3.73 (d, J = 13.4 Hz, 1H), 2.35–2.28 (m, 1H), 1.18–1.12 (m, 2H), 1.07 (br s, 2H); 13C (125.75 MHz, CDCl3) δ = 173.9 (C), 159.5 (C), 159.3 (C), 130.9 (2CH), 130.1 (2CH), 128.2 (C), 126.4 (C), 116.7 (CH), 114.4 (2CH), 114.0 (2CH), 68.4 (CH), 55.3 (2CH3), 51.2 (CH2), 14.5 (CH), 11.2 (2CH2).

    5-({[Bis(4-chlorophenyl)methyl]sulfinyl}methyl)thiazole (24h)

    30% H2O2 (0.2 mL) was added to the solution of 23h (0.66 g, 1.8 mmol) in glacial acetic acid (10 mL). The reaction mixture was stirred at room temperature during 24 h. Then, the reaction mixture was neutralized with cold 5% sodium bicarbonate solution. The reaction product was extracted (3 × 50 mL) with EtOAc and dried over anhydrous Na2SO4. The organic solution was concentrated under reduced pressure and the residue purified by flash column chromatography on silica gel (5% MeOH in DCM). The product was dried in high vacuum to give 0.18 g of 24h as a pale-brown solid (yield 26%). Ret. time 20.52 min, purity 99.3%. HRESIMS m/z 403.9707 [M + Na]+ (calcd for C17H13Cl2NNaOS2+, 403.9708, Δ = 0.3 ppm). 1H NMR (500 MHz, CDCl3) δ = 8.88 (s, 1H), 7.69 (s, 1H), 7.45 (d, J = 8.3 Hz, 2H), 7.35–7.27 (m, 6H), 4.58 (s, 1H), 4.15 (d, J = 14.5 Hz, 1H), 3.90 (d, J = 14.5 Hz, 1H); 13C NMR (125.75 MHz, CDCl3) δ = 151.2 (CH), 144.2 (CH), 135.1 (C), 135.0 (C), 132.8 (C), 131.9 (C), 130.6 (2CH), 130.0 (2CH), 129.9 (2CH), 129.1 (2CH), 124.5 (C), 67.9 (CH), 46.7 (CH2).

    4-({[(4-Bromophenyl)(phenyl)methyl]sulfinyl}methyl)thiazole (24i)

    30% H2O2 (0.4 mL) was added to the solution of 23i (1.3 g, 3.4 mmol) in glacial acetic acid (20 mL). The reaction mixture was stirred at room temperature during 24 h. Then, the reaction mixture was neutralized with cold 5% sodium bicarbonate solution. The reaction product was extracted (3 × 50 mL) with EtOAc and dried over anhydrous Na2SO4. The organic solution was concentrated under reduced pressure and the residue purified by flash column chromatography on silica gel (5% MeOH in DCM). The product was dried in high vacuum to give 1.22 g of 24i as a white solid (yield 92%). Ret. time 19.93 min, purity 97.76%. HRESIMS m/z 413.9591 [M + Na]+ (calcd for C17H14BrNNaOS2+, 413.9592, Δ = 0.3 ppm).

    2-({[Bis(4-chlorophenyl)methyl]sulfinyl}methyl)thiazole (24j)

    30% H2O2 (0.1 mL) was added to the solution of 23j (0.24 g, 0.6 mmol) in glacial acetic acid (10 mL). The reaction mixture was stirred at room temperature during 24 h. Then, the reaction mixture was neutralized with cold 5% sodium bicarbonate solution. The reaction product was extracted (3 × 50 mL) with EtOAc and dried over anhydrous Na2SO4. The organic solution was concentrated under reduced pressure and the residue purified by flash column chromatography on silica gel (2.5% MeOH in DCM). The product was dried in high vacuum to give 0.07 g of 24j as yellow powder (yield 31%). Ret. time 24.25 min, purity 99.8%.     5-({[Bis(4-fluorophenyl)methyl]sulfinyl}methyl)thiazole (24k)

    30% H2O2 (0.2 mL) was added to the solution of 23k (0.5 g, 1.4 mmol) in glacial acetic acid (10 mL). The reaction mixture was stirred at room temperature during 24 h. Then, the reaction mixture was neutralized with cold 5% sodium bicarbonate solution. The reaction product was extracted (3 × 50 mL) with EtOAc and dried over anhydrous Na2SO4. The organic solution was concentrated under reduced pressure and the residue purified by flash column chromatography on silica gel (2.5% MeOH in DCM). The product was dried in high vacuum to give 0.08 g of 24k as yellow powder (yield 16%). Mp 103–109 °C. Ret. time 17.64 min, purity 96.1%.     5-({[Bis(4-methylphenyl)methyl]sulfinyl}methyl)thiazole (24l)

    30% H2O2 (0.15 mL) was added to the solution of 23l (0.4 g, 1.2 mmol) in glacial acetic acid (10 mL). The reaction mixture was stirred at room temperature during 24 h. Then, the reaction mixture was neutralized with cold 5% sodium bicarbonate solution. The reaction product was extracted (3 × 50 mL) with EtOAc and dried over anhydrous Na2SO4. The organic solution was concentrated under reduced pressure and the residue purified by flash column chromatography on silica gel (5% MeOH in DCM). The product was dried in high vacuum to give 0.14 g of 24l as a pale-yellow solid (yield 35%). Mp 107–109 °C. Ret. time 19.46 min, purity 98.4%.     2-({[Bis(4-methylphenyl)methyl]sulfinyl}methyl)thiazole (24m)

    30% H2O2 (0.2 mL) was added to the solution of 23m (0.57 g, 1.8 mmol) in glacial acetic acid (10 mL). The reaction mixture was stirred at room temperature during 24 h. Then, the reaction mixture was neutralized with cold 5% sodium bicarbonate solution. The reaction product was extracted (3 × 50 mL) with EtOAc and dried over anhydrous Na2SO4. The organic solution was concentrated under reduced pressure and the residue purified by flash column chromatography on silica gel (5% MeOH in DCM). The product was dried in high vacuum to give 0.18 g of 24m as pale yellow-brown solid (yield 30%). Mp 129–131 °C. Ret. time 20.76 min, purity 99.6%. HRESIMS m/z 364.0802 [M + Na]+ (calcd for C19H19NNaOS2+, 364.0800, Δ = 0.6 ppm). 1H NMR (500 MHz, CDCl3) δ = 7.88 (s, 1H), 7.39–7.33 (m, 5H), 7.22–7.16 (m, 4H), 5.02 (s, 1H), 4.26 (d, J = 13.8 Hz, 1H), 4.04 (d, J = 13.8 Hz, 1H), 2.35 (s, 3H), 2.32 (s, 3H); 13C NMR (125.75 MHz, CDCl3) δ = 158.2 (C), 143.0 (CH), 138.3 (C), 138.2 (C), 132.3 (C), 130.9 (C), 129.9 (2CH), 129.6 (2CH), 129.4 (2C), 128.8 (2CH), 121.2 (CH), 69.8 (CH), 52.0 (CH2), 21.1 (2CH3).

    4-({(R)-[(R)-(4-Bromophenyl)(phenyl)methyl]sulfinyl}methyl)thiazole (31c), 4-({(S)-[(R)-(4-Bromophenyl)(phenyl)methyl]sulfinyl}methyl)thiazole (31d), 4-({(S)-[(S)-(4-Bromophenyl)(phenyl)methyl]sulfinyl}methyl)thiazole (31e), and 4-({(R)-[(S)-(4-Bromophenyl)(phenyl)methyl]sulfinyl}methyl)thiazole (31f)

    The starting point for synthesis of 31c–f is the same: 4-(chloromethyl)thiazole was reacted with thioacetic acid to yield the thioester 27, which was hydrolyzed under alkaline conditions to the corresponding mercaptan 29. Thiazol-4-ylmethanethiol (29) was reacted with (4-bromophenyl)(phenyl)methanol (28) to yield racemic 4-({[(4-bromophenyl)(phenyl)methyl]thio}methyl)thiazole (30) in 25% yield. In the following step, compound 30 was separated using semipreparative HPLC equipped with CHIRALPAK IA column (10 mm ⌀ × 25 cm L) (Daicel Inc., Tokyo, Japan) and acetonitrile as the mobile phase into the individual enantiomers 30a and 30b. Each of the enantiomers was further oxidized to yield the racemic compounds 31a and 31b, respectively, that were finally separated using semipreparative HPLC equipped with CHIRALPAK IA column into individual stereoisomers 31c–f (Scheme 4). All separations were carried out at room temperature using a flow rate of 10 mL/min.
    31c. Ret. time 21.38 min, purity 96.3%. HRESIMS m/z 413.9595 [M + Na]+ (calcd for C17H14BrNNaOS2+, 413.9592, Δ = 0.6 ppm). 1H NMR (500 MHz, CDCl3) δ = 8.90 (d, J = 1.95 Hz, 1H), 7.53–7.36 (m, 10H), 5.05 (s, 1H), 4.16 (d, J = 15 Hz, 1H), 3.89 (d, J = 15 Hz, 1H); 13C NMR (125.75 MHz, CDCl3) δ = 153.3 (CH), 145.6 (C), 134.9 (C), 133.5 (C), 132.2 (2CH), 130.6 (2CH), 129.7 (2CH), 128.7 (2CH), 128.5 (p-CH), 122.5 (p-C), 119.5 (CH), 69.0 (CH), 50.8 (CH2).
    31d. Ret. time 21.43 min, purity 99.0%. HRESIMS m/z 413.9593 [M + Na]+ (calcd for C17H14BrNNaOS2+, 413.9592, Δ = 0.0 ppm). 1H NMR (500 MHz, CDCl3) δ = 8.86 (d, J = 1.9 Hz, 1H), 7.51–7.34 (m, 10H), 5.06 (s, 1H), 4.11 (d, J = 15 Hz, 1H), 3.91 (d, J = 15 Hz, 1H); 13C NMR (125.75 MHz, CDCl3) δ = 153.2 (CH), 145.8 (C), 135.2 (C), 133.1 (C), 131.7 (2CH), 131.4 (2CH), 129.3 (2CH), 128.8 (2CH), 128.5 (p-CH), 122.7 (p-C), 119.4 (CH), 69.1 (CH), 50.9 (CH2).
    31e. Ret. time 21.40 min, purity 97.1%. HRESIMS m/z 413.9591 [M + Na]+ (calcd for C17H14BrNNaOS2+, 413.9592, Δ = 0.3 ppm). 1H NMR (500 MHz, CDCl3) δ = 8.89 (d, J = 1.95 Hz, 1H), 7.53–7.35 (m, 10H), 5.04 (s, 1H), 4.16 (d, J = 15 Hz, 1H), 3.87 (d, J = 15 Hz, 1H); 13C NMR (125.75 MHz, CDCl3) δ = 153.3 (CH), 145.6 (C), 134.9 (C), 133.5 (C), 132.2 (2CH), 130.6 (2CH), 129.7 (2CH), 128.7 (2CH), 128.5 (p-CH), 122.5 (p-C), 119.5 (CH), 69.0 (CH), 50.9 (CH2).
    31f. Ret. time 21.43 min, purity 98.8%. HRESIMS m/z 413.9592 [M + Na]+ (calcd for C17H14BrNNaOS2+, 413.9592, Δ = 0.2 ppm). 1H NMR (500 MHz, CDCl3) δ = 8.89 (d, J = 2.0 Hz, 1H), 7.50–7.35 (m, 10H), 5.08 (s, 1H), 4.13 (d, J = 15 Hz, 1H), 3.92 (d, J = 15 Hz, 1H); 13C NMR (125.75 MHz, CDCl3) δ = 153.3 (CH), 145.6 (C), 135.2 (C), 133.1 (C), 131.7 (2CH), 131.4 (2CH), 129.3 (2CH), 128.9 (2CH), 128.5 (p-CH), 122.7 (p-C), 119.5 (CH), 69.2 (CH), 50.9 (CH2).

    (S)-5-({[Bis(4-chlorophenyl)methyl]sulfinyl}methyl)thiazole (32a)

    The less retained enantiomer of 24h was obtained through chiral separations using semipreparative HPLC equipped with CHIRALPAK IA column (10 mm ⌀ × 25 cm L) (Daicel Inc., Tokyo, Japan) and ethyl acetate as the mobile phase into the individual enantiomers. Separations were carried out at room temperature using a flow rate of 10 mL/min. White powder. Mp 137–139 °C. Ret. time 24.02 min, purity 98.36%. HRESIMS m/z 403.9702 [M + Na]+ (calcd for C17H13Cl2NNaOS2+, 403.9708, Δ = −1.3 ppm). 1H NMR (500 MHz, CDCl3) δ = 8.87 (s, 1H), 7.69 (s, 1H), 7.44 (d, J = 8.5 Hz, 2H), 7.35–7.27 (m, 6H), 4.58 (s, 1H), 4.14 (d, J = 14.4 Hz, 1H), 3.89 (d, J = 14.4 Hz, 1H); 13C NMR (125.75 MHz, CDCl3) δ = 155.1 (CH), 144.2 (CH), 135.1 (C–Cl), 135.0 (C–Cl), 132.8 (C), 131.9 (C), 130.6 (2CH), 130.0 (2CH), 129.9 (2CH), 129.1 (2CH), 124.6 (C), 68.0 (CH), 46.8 (CH2).

    (R)-5-({[Bis(4-chlorophenyl)methyl]sulfinyl}methyl)thiazole (32b)

    The more retained enantiomer of 24h was obtained through chiral separations using semipreparative HPLC equipped with CHIRALPAK IA column (10 mm ⌀ × 25 cm L) (Daicel Inc., Tokyo, Japan) and ethyl acetate as the mobile phase into the individual enantiomers. Separations were carried out at room temperature using a flow rate of 10 mL/min. White powder. Mp 139–141 °C. Ret. time 24.00 min, purity 99.84%.     (S)-5-({[Bis(4-fluorophenyl)methyl]sulfinyl}methyl)thiazole (33a)

    The less retained enantiomer of 24k was obtained through chiral separations using semipreparative HPLC equipped with CHIRALPAK IA column (10 mm ⌀ × 25 cm L) (Daicel Inc., Tokyo, Japan) and ethyl acetate as the mobile phase into the individual enantiomers.     (R)-5-({[Bis(4-fluorophenyl)methyl]sulfinyl}methyl)thiazole (33b)

    The more retained enantiomer of 24k was obtained through chiral separations using semipreparative HPLC equipped with CHIRALPAK IA column (10 mm ⌀ × 25 cm L) (Daicel Inc., Tokyo, Japan) and ethyl acetate as the mobile phase into the individual enantiomers.     Less Retained Enantiomer 5-({[Bis(4-methylphenyl)methyl]sulfinyl}methyl)thiazole (34a)

    The less retained enantiomer of 24l was obtained through chiral separations using semipreparative HPLC equipped with CHIRALPAK IA column (10 mm ⌀ × 25 cm L) (Daicel Inc., Tokyo, Japan) and ethyl acetate as the mobile phase into the individual enantiomers. Separations were carried out at room temperature using a flow rate of 10 mL/min. Transparent oil. Ret. time 22.65 min, purity 98.42%. HRESIMS m/z 364.0798 [M + Na]+ (calcd for C19H19NNaOS2+, 364.0800, Δ = 0.7 ppm). 1H NMR (500 MHz, CDCl3) δ = 8.83 (s, 1H), 7.66 (s, 1H), 7.26–7.22 (m, 6H), 7.14 (d, J = 8 Hz, 2H), 4.58 (s, 1H), 4.10 (d, J = 14.4 Hz, 1H), 3.87 (d, J = 14.4 Hz, 1H), 2.36 (s, 3H), 2.30 (s, 3H); 13C NMR (125.75 MHz, CDCl3) δ = 154.8 (CH), 144.1 (CH), 138.6 (C), 138.4 (C), 131.9 (C), 131.3 (C), 130.2 (2CH), 129.5 (2CH), 129.2 (2CH), 128.5 (2CH), 125.2 (C), 69.6 (CH), 46.6 (CH2), 21.2 (CH3), 21.1 (CH3).

    More Retained Enantiomer 5-({[Bis(4-methylphenyl)methyl]sulfinyl}methyl)thiazole (34b)

    The more retained enantiomer of 24l was obtained through chiral separations using semipreparative HPLC equipped with CHIRALPAK IA column (10 mm ⌀ × 25 cm L) (Daicel Inc., Tokyo, Japan) and ethyl acetate as the mobile phase into the individual enantiomers. Separations were carried out at room temperature using a flow rate of 10 mL/min. White powder. Mp 99–102 °C. Ret. time 22.65 min, purity 99.15%. HRESIMS m/z 364.0796 [M + Na]+ (calcd for C19H19NNaOS2+, 364.0800, Δ = 1.1 ppm). 1H NMR (500 MHz, CDCl3) δ = 8.83 (s, 1H), 7.66 (s, 1H), 7.26–7.21 (m, 6H), 7.14 (d, J = 8 Hz, 2H), 4.58 (s, 1H), 4.10 (d, J = 14.3 Hz, 1H), 3.87 (d, J = 14.3 Hz, 1H), 2.36 (s, 3H), 2.30 (s, 3H); 13C NMR (125.75 MHz, CDCl3) δ = 154.8 (CH), 144.1 (CH), 138.6 (C), 138.3 (C), 131.9 (C), 131.3 (C), 130.1 (2CH), 129.5 (2CH), 129.2 (2CH), 128.5 (2CH), 125.1 (C), 69.6 (CH), 46.6 (CH2), 21.2 (CH3), 21.1 (CH3).

    5-(4-Trifluoromethylphenyl)(phenyl)methyl]sulfinyl}methyl)thiazole (42a), 5-(4-Trifluoromethylphenyl)(phenyl)methyl]sulfinyl}methyl)thiazole (43a), 5-({(S)-[(R)-(4-Trifluoromethylphenyl)(phenyl)methyl]sulfinyl}methyl)thiazole (44a), and 5-({(R)-[(R)-(4-Trifluoromethylphenyl)(phenyl)methyl]sulfinyl}methyl)thiazole (45a)

    Thiazol-5-ylmethanethiol (0.5 g, 3.8 mmol) (36) was reacted with (4-trifluorophenyl)(phenyl)methanol (0.9 g, 3.8 mmol) (35a) and boron trifluoride diethyl etherate to yield 1.2 g of racemic 5-({[(4-trifluorophenyl)(phenyl)methyl]thio}methyl)thiazole (37a) in 86% yield. In the following step, compound 37a was separated using semipreparative HPLC equipped with CHIRALPAK IA column (10 mm ⌀ × 25 cm L) (Daicel Inc., Tokyo, Japan) and absolute ethanol as the mobile phase into the individual (less retained and more retained) enantiomers 38a and 39a, respectively. Each of the enantiomers was further oxidized to yield the racemic compounds 40a and 41a (84% and 90% yield), respectively, that were finally separated using semipreparative HPLC equipped with CHIRALPAK IA column and 100% EtOAc as the mobile phase into individual stereoisomers 42a–a (Scheme 5). All separations were carried out at room temperature using a flow rate of 10 mL/min.
    42a. White powder. Mp 125–129 °C. Ret. time 22.38 min, purity 99.31%.     5-({(S)-[(S)-(4-Chlorophenyl)(phenyl)methyl]sulfinyl}methyl)thiazole (42b), 5-({(R)-[(S)-(4-Chlorophenyl)(phenyl)methyl]sulfinyl}methyl)thiazole (43b), 5-({(S)-[(R)-(4-Chlorophenyl)(phenyl)methyl]sulfinyl}methyl)thiazole (44b), and 5-({(R)-[(R)-(4-Chlorophenyl)(phenyl)methyl]sulfinyl}methyl)thiazole (45b)

    The starting point for synthesis of 42b–45b is the same: Thiazol-5-ylmethanethiol (0.5 g, 3.8 mmol) (36) was reacted with (4-chlorophenyl)(phenyl)methanol (0.8 g, 3.8 mmol) (35b) and 1.1. equiv of boron trifluoride diethyl etherate to yield 1.1 g of racemic 5-({[(4-chlorophenyl)(phenyl)methyl]thio}methyl)thiazole (37b) in 87% yield. In the following step, compound 37b was separated using semipreparative HPLC equipped with CHIRALPAK IA column (10 mm ⌀ × 25 cm L) (Daicel Inc., Tokyo, Japan) and absolute ethanol as the mobile phase into the individual (less retained and more retained) enantiomers 38b and 39b, respectively. Each of the enantiomers was further oxidized to yield the racemic compounds 40b and 41b (89% and 85% yield), respectively, that were finally separated using semipreparative HPLC equipped with CHIRALPAK IA column and 100% EtOAc as mobile phase into individual stereoisomers 42b–45b (Scheme 5). All separations were carried out at room temperature using a flow rate of 10 mL/min.
    42b. White powder. Mp 134–136 °C. Ret. time 21.67 min, purity 99.44%. HRESIMS m/z 348.0275 [M + H]+ (calcd for C17H15ClNOS2+, 348.0278, Δ = −1.0 ppm). 1H NMR (500 MHz, CDCl3) δ = 8.86 (s, 1H), 7.70 (s, 1H), 7.42 (d, J = 8.5 Hz, 2H), 7.37–7.32 (m, 7H), 4.62 (s, 1H), 4.14 (d, J = 14.3 Hz, 1H), 3.89 (d, J = 14.3 Hz, 1H); 13C NMR (125.75 MHz, CDCl3) δ = 155.0 (CH), 144.2 (CH), 134.8 (C), 133.5 (C), 133.4 (C), 130.0 (2CH), 129.7 (2CH), 129.3 (2CH), 128.9 (2CH), 128.8 (CH), 124.9 (C), 68.8 (CH), 46.8 (CH2).
    43b. White powder. Mp 125–128 °C. Ret. time 21.65 min, purity 98.97%. HRESIMS m/z 348.0276 [M + H]+ (calcd for C17H15ClNOS2+, 348.0278, Δ = −0.6 ppm). 1H NMR (500 MHz, CDCl3) δ = 8.88 (s, 1H), 7.68 (s, 1H), 7.48–7.41 (m, 3H), 7.36–7.30 (m, 6H), 4.61 (s, 1H), 4.14 (d, J = 14.4 Hz, 1H), 3.89 (d, J = 14.4 Hz, 1H); 13C NMR (125.75 MHz, CDCl3) δ = 155.1 (CH), 144.1 (CH), 134.8 (C), 134.2 (C), 132.6 (C), 130.7 (2CH), 129.7 (2CH), 129.0 (CH), 128.9 (2CH), 128.6 (2CH), 124.7 (C), 69.2 (CH), 46.7 (CH2).
    44b. White powder. Mp 123–125 °C. Ret. time 21.65 min, purity 99.19%. HRESIMS m/z 348.0273 [M + H]+ (calcd for C17H15ClNOS2+, 348.0278, Δ = −1.4 ppm). 1H NMR (500 MHz, CDCl3) δ = 8.88 (s, 1H), 7.68 (s, 1H), 7.48–7.41 (m, 3H), 7.36–7.30 (m, 6H), 4.61 (s, 1H), 4.14 (d, J = 14.4 Hz, 1H), 3.89 (d, J = 14.4 Hz, 1H); 13C NMR (125.75 MHz, CDCl3) δ = 155.1 (CH), 144.1 (CH), 134.8 (C), 134.2 (C), 132.6 (C), 130.7 (2CH), 129.7 (2CH), 129.0 (CH), 128.9 (2CH), 128.6 (2CH), 124.7 (C), 69.2 (CH), 46.7 (CH2).
    45b. White powder. Mp 136–139 °C. Ret. time 21.65 min, purity 99.62%. HRESIMS m/z 348.0280 [M + H]+ (calcd for C17H15ClNOS2+, 348.0278, Δ = −0.5 ppm). 1H NMR (500 MHz, CDCl3) δ = 8.86 (s, 1H), 7.42 (d, J = 8.5 Hz, 2H), 7.38–7.34 (m, 7H), 4.62 (s, 1H), 4.14 (d, J = 14.4 Hz, 1H), 3.89 (d, J = 14.4 Hz, 1H); 13C NMR (125.75 MHz, CDCl3) δ = 154.9 (CH), 144.2 (CH), 134.8 (C), 133.5 (C), 133.4 (C), 130.0 (2CH), 129.7 (2CH), 129.3 (2CH), 128.9 (2CH), 128.8 (CH), 124.9 (C), 68.8 (CH), 46.8 (CH2).

    5-({(S)-[(R)-(4-Methylyphenyl)(phenyl)methyl]sulfinyl}methyl)thiazole (42c), 5-({(R)-[(R)-(4-Methylphenyl)(phenyl)methyl]sulfinyl}methyl)thiazole (43c), 5-({(S)-[(S)-(4-Methylphenyl)(phenyl)methyl]sulfinyl}methyl)thiazole (44c), and 5-({(R)-[(S)-(4-Methylphenyl)(phenyl)methyl]sulfinyl}methyl)thiazole (45c)

    The starting point for synthesis of 42c–45c is the same: Thiazol-5-ylmethanethiol (0.5 g, 3.8 mmol) (36) was reacted with (4-methylphenyl)(phenyl)methanol (0.7 g, 3.8 mmol) (35c) and 1.1. equiv of boron trifluoride diethyl etharate to yield 1 g of racemic 5-({[(4-methylphenyl)(phenyl)methyl]thio}methyl)thiazole (37c) in 85% yield. In the following step, compound 37c was separated using semipreparative HPLC equipped with CHIRALPAK IA column (10 mm ⌀ × 25 cm L) (Daicel Inc., Tokyo, Japan) and ethyl acetate/hexane (1/1, v/v) as the mobile phase into the individual (less retained and more retained) enantiomers 38c and 39c, respectively. Each of the enantiomers was further oxidized to yield the racemic compounds 40c and 41c (91% and 76% yield), respectively, that were finally separated using semipreparative HPLC equipped with CHIRALPAK IA column and 100% EtOAc as mobile phase into individual stereoisomers 42c–45c (Scheme 5). All separations were carried out at room temperature using a flow rate of 10 mL/min.

    43c. White powder. Mp 111–115 °C. Ret. time 21.07 min, purity 99.63%.     5-({(S)-[(R)-(4-Methoxyphenyl)(phenyl)methyl]sulfinyl}methyl)thiazole (42d), 5-({(R)-[(R)-(4-Methoxyphenyl)(phenyl)methyl]sulfinyl}methyl)thiazole (43d), 5-({(S)-[(S)-(4-Methoxyphenyl)(phenyl)methyl]sulfinyl}methyl)thiazole (44d), 5-({(R)-[(S)-(4-Methoxyphenyl)(phenyl)methyl]sulfinyl}methyl)thiazole (45d)

    The starting point for synthesis of 42d–45d is the same: Thiazol-5-ylmethanethiol (0.5 g, 3.8 mmol) (36) was reacted with (4-methoxyphenyl)(phenyl)methanol (0.8 g, 3.8 mmol) (35d) and 1.1 equiv of boron trifluoride diethyl etharate to yield 1 g of racemic 5-({[(4-methoxyphenyl)(phenyl)methyl]thio}methyl)thiazole (37d) in 80% yield. In the following step, compound 37d was separated using semipreparative HPLC equipped with CHIRALPAK IA column (10 mm ⌀ × 25 cm L) (Daicel Inc., Tokyo, Japan) and ethyl acetate/hexane (1/1, v/v) as the mobile phase into the individual (less retained and more retained) enantiomers 38d and 39d, respectively. Each of the enantiomers was further oxidized to yield the racemic compounds 40d and 41d (95% and 96% yield), respectively, that were finally separated using semipreparative HPLC equipped with CHIRALPAK IA column and 100% EtOAc as mobile phase into individual stereoisomers 42d–45d (Scheme 5).     5-({(S)-[(S)-(4-Bromophenyl)(phenyl)methyl]sulfinyl}methyl)thiazole (42e), 5-({(R)-[(S)-(4-Bromophenyl)(phenyl)methyl]sulfinyl}methyl)thiazole (43e), 5-({(S)-[(R)-(4-Bromophenyl)(phenyl)methyl]sulfinyl}methyl)thiazole (44e), and 5-({(R)-[(R)-(4-Bromophenyl)(phenyl)methyl]sulfinyl}methyl)thiazole (45e)

    The starting point for the synthesis of 42e–45e is the same: Thiazol-5-ylmethanethiol (36) was reacted with (4-bromophenyl)(phenyl)methanol (1.5 g, 5.7 mmol) (35e) and 1.1 equiv of boron trifluoride diethyl etharate to yield 0.48 g of racemic 5-({[(4-bromophenyl)(phenyl)methyl]thio}methyl)thiazole (37e) in 22% yield. Each of the enantiomers was further oxidized to yield the racemic compounds 40e and 41e (81% and 79% yield), respectively, that were finally separated using semipreparative HPLC equipped with CHIRALPAK IA column and 100% EtOAc as mobile phase into individual stereoisomers 42e–45e (Scheme 5).     5-({(S)-[(S)-(4-Fluorophenyl)(phenyl)methyl]sulfinyl}methyl)thiazole (42f), 5-({(R)-[(S)-(4-Fluorophenyl)(phenyl)methyl]sulfinyl}methyl)thiazole (43f), 5-({(S)-[(R)-(4-Fluorophenyl)(phenyl)methyl]sulfinyl}methyl)thiazole (44f), and 5-({(R)-[(R)-(4-Fluorophenyl)(phenyl)methyl]sulfinyl}methyl)thiazole (45f)

    The starting point for synthesis of 42f–45f is the same: Thiazol-5-ylmethanethiol (0.5 g, 3.8 mmol) (36) was reacted with (4-fluorophenyl)(phenyl)methanol (0.7 g, 3.8 mmol) (35f) and boron trifluoride diethyl etherate to yield 1.0 g of racemic 5-({[(4-fluorophenyl)(phenyl)methyl]thio}methyl)thiazole (37f) in 85% yield. In the following step, compound 37f was separated using semipreparative HPLC equipped with CHIRALPAK IA column (10 mm ⌀ × 25 cm L) (Daicel Inc., Tokyo, Japan) and absolute ethanol as the mobile phase into the individual (less retained and more retained) enantiomers 38f and 39f, respectively. Each of the enantiomers was further oxidized to yield the racemic compounds 40f and 41f (94% and 93% yield), respectively, that were finally separated using semipreparative HPLC equipped with CHIRALPAK IA column into individual stereoisomers 42f–45f (Scheme 5). All separations were carried out at room temperature using a flow rate of 10 mL/min.
    42f. White powder. Mp 122–123 °C. Ret. time 19.77 min, purity 99.60%. HRESIMS m/z 332.0575 [M + H]+ (calcd for C17H15FNOS2+, 332.0574, Δ = 0.5 ppm). 1H NMR (500 MHz, CDCl3) δ = 8.86 (s, 1H), 7.69 (s, 1H), 7.40–7.36 (m, 7H), 7.16–7.13 (m, 2H), 4.64 (s, 1H), 4.13 (d, J = 14.4 Hz, 1H), 3.88 (d, J = 14.4 Hz, 1H); 13C NMR (125.75 MHz, CDCl3) δ = 162.7 (d, 1J(13C, 19F) = 248.8 Hz, CF), 155.0 (CH), 144.1 (CH), 133.7 (C), 130.8 (d, 4J(13C, 19F) = 3.4 Hz, C), 130.4 (d, 3J(13C, 19F) = 8.1 Hz, 2CH), 129.3 (2CH), 128.9 (2CH), 128.9 (CH), 125.0 (C), 116.6 (d, 2J(13C, 19F) = 21.2 Hz, 2CH), 68.8 (CH), 46.8 (CH2).
    43f. White powder. Mp 116–118 °C. Ret. time 19.83 min, purity 99.50%. HRESIMS m/z 332.0575 [M + H]+ (calcd for C17H15FNOS2+, 332.0574, Δ = −0.5 ppm). 1H NMR (500 MHz, CDCl3) δ = 8.86 (s, 1H), 7.67 (s, 1H), 7.48–7.40 (m, 3H), 3.37–7.33 (m, 4H), 7.06–7.03 (m, 2H), 4.62 (s, 1H), 4.13 (d, J = 14.4 Hz, 1H), 3.89 (d, J = 14.4 Hz, 1H); 13C NMR (125.75 MHz, CDCl3) δ = 162.9 (d, 1J(13C, 19F) = 247.8 Hz, CF), 155.0 (CH), 144.2 (CH), 134.5 (C), 131.1 (d, 3J(13C, 19F) = 8.1 Hz, 2CH), 129.9 (d, 4J(13C, 19F) = 3.3 Hz, C), 129.7 (2CH), 128.9 (CH), 128.6 (2CH), 124.7 (C), 115.8 (d, 2J(13C, 19F) = 21.6 Hz, 2CH), 69.0 (CH), 46.6 (CH2).
    44f. White powder. Mp 117–119 °C. Ret. time 19.83 min, purity 99.58%. HRESIMS m/z 332.0573 [M + H]+ (calcd for C17H15FNOS2+, 332.0574, Δ = 0.3 ppm). 1H NMR (500 MHz, CDCl3) δ = 8.86 (s, 1H), 7.67 (s, 1H), 7.48–7.40 (m, 3H), 7.37–7.34 (m, 4H), 7.06–7.03 (m, 2H), 4.62 (s, 1H), 4.13 (d, J = 14.4 Hz, 1H), 3.87 (d, J = 14.4 Hz, 1H); 13C NMR (125.75 MHz, CDCl3) δ = 162.9 (d, 1J(13C, 19F) = 247.7 Hz, CF), 155.0 (CH), 144.2 (CH), 134.5 (C), 131.1 (d, 3J(13C, 19F) = 8.2 Hz, 2CH), 129.8 (d, 4J(13C, 19F) = 3.3 Hz, C), 129.7 (2CH), 128.9 (CH), 128.6 (2CH), 124.7 (C), 115.8 (d, 2J(13C, 19F) = 19.0 Hz, 2CH), 69.0 (CH), 46.6 (CH2).
    45f. White powder. Mp 122–124 °C.Ret. time 19.77 min, purity 99.59%. HRESIMS m/z 332.0574 [M + H]+ (calcd for C17H15FNOS2+, 332.0574, Δ = 0.1 ppm). 1H NMR (500 MHz, CDCl3) δ = 8.86 (s, 1H), 7.69 (s, 1H), 7.40–7.36 (m, 7H), 7.16–7.13 (m, 2H), 4.64 (s, 1H), 4.13 (d, J = 14.4 Hz, 1H), 3.88 (d, J = 14.4 Hz, 1H); 13C NMR (125.75 MHz, CDCl3) δ = 162.7 (d, 1J(13C, 19F) = 248.9 Hz, CF), 154.9 (CH), 144.1 (CH), 133.7 (C), 130.8 (d, 4J(13C, 19F) = 3.4 Hz, C), 130.4 (d, 3J(13C, 19F) = 8.1 Hz, 2CH), 129.3 (2CH), 129.0 (2CH), 128.7 (CH), 125.0 (C), 116.5 (d, 2J(13C, 19F) = 21.3 Hz, 2CH), 68.8 (CH), 46.8 (CH2).

    X-ray Measurements

    The X-ray intensity data were measured on Bruker D8 Venture diffractometer equipped with multilayer monochromator, Mo K/a INCOATEC microfocus sealed tube and Oxford cooling system. The structures were solved by direct methods and refined by full-matrix least-squares techniques. Non-hydrogen atoms were refined with anisotropic displacement parameters. Hydrogen atoms were inserted at calculated positions and refined with riding model. The following software was used: Bruker SAINT software package(39) using a narrow-frame algorithm for frame integration, SADABS(40) for absorption correction, OLEX2(41) for structure solution, refinement, molecular diagrams and graphical user interface Shelxle(42) for refinement and graphical user-interface SHELXS-2013(43) for structure solution, SHELXL-2013(44) for refinement, Platon(45) for symmetry check. Experimental data and CCDC codes can be found in Supporting Information. Crystal data, data collection parameters, and structure refinement details as well as crystal structures visualized are available in Supporting Information.

    Monoamine Transporter Uptake Inhibition Assays

    Uptake inhibition measurements were performed as described previously.(34,46) Dulbecco’s modified Eagle’s medium (DMEM), trypsin, and fetal calf serum (FCS) were purchased from Sigma-Aldrich Handels GmbH (Austria). [3H]5-HT (hydroxytryptamine creatinine sulfate; 5-[1,2-3H[N]]; 45.3 Ci/mmol), [3H]DA (dihydroxyphenylethylamine; 3,4-[ring-2,5,6-3[H]]-dopamine; 55.8 Ci/mmol), and [3H]MPP+ (methyl-4-phenylpyridinium iodide; 1-[methyl-3H]; 80 Ci/mmol) were purchased from PerkinElmer, Boston, MA.
    HEK293 cells stably expressing human isoforms of the dopamine transporter (HEK DATwt), norepinephrine transporter (HEK NETwt), and serotonin transporter (HEK SERTwt) were used for uptake inhibition assays. All cell lines were grown as monolayers in 96-well plates precoated with poly-d-lysine (PDL) (4 × 104 cells/well) 24 h prior to the experiment. On the day of the experiment, the medium was aspirated, and each well was washed with 0.1 mL of warm (30 °C) Krebs-HEPES buffer (KHB; 10 mM HEPES, 120 mM NaCl, 3 mM KCl, 2 mM CaCl2·2H2O, 2 mM MgCl2·6 H2O, 5 mM d-(+)-glucose, pH 7.3). The cells were preincubated for 5 min in KHB containing 1% of dimethyl sulfoxide and increasing concentrations of the test compounds (0.1 μM to 1 mM). After aspiration of the preincubation solution, the cells were incubated in KHB containing increasing concentrations of the compound with the addition of 0.2 μM [3H]-dopamine (for HEK DATwt), 0.02 μM [3H]-MPP+ (for HEK NETwt), and 0.2 μM [3H]-5-HT (for HEK SERTwt). Incubation times were 1 min for HEK DATwt and HEK SERTwt and 3 min for HEK NETwt. Nonspecific [3H]-dopamine and [3H]-MPP+ uptake in the presence of 30 μM cocaine was subtracted from total uptake. Nonspecific [3H]-5-HT uptake in the presence of 30 μM paroxetine was subtracted from total uptake. After incubation at room temperature, reactions were stopped by the addition of 0.1 mL of ice-cold KHB. Finally, cells were lysed with 0.3 mL of 1% SDS, and released radioactivity was measured by a liquid scintillation counter (Tri-carb-2300TR, PerkinElmer).
    Nonlinear regression analysis (GraphPad Prism version 5.0, GraphPad Software, San Diego, CA, USA) was used for calculation of IC50 values.

    In Silico Methods. Homology Modeling

    The homology model of the human dopamine transporter (hDAT) was kindly provided by Prof. Dr. Gerhard Ecker from the University of Vienna, Vienna, Austria. The homology model, first described by Saha et al. 2015,(47) is based on the crystallized Drosophila melanogaster DAT (dDAT) structure in complex with nortriptyline (PDB code 4M48).(48)

    Docking

    Molecular docking of compounds 31c–f and the hDAT was performed using AutoDock Vina.(49) The ligands were prepared with flexible bonds using the automatic detection of AutoDock Vina. For the molecular docking run, standard parameters were used, protein flexibility was not regarded, and the exhaustiveness level was set to 16. Water molecules were removed (but ions in the binding site were retained), and the binding site was defined as the center of mass of nortriptyline. The search space was restricted to the protein structure. Interactions between docked ligand and transporter were analyzed using LigandScout 4.3.(50)

    In Silico Toxicity Profiling

    The Inte:Ligand Tox Pharmacophore DB(51) was used for toxicity profiling of compounds within a KNIME(52) workflow.

    In Vitro Action Potential Measurements

    Before the experiments, Cor.4U hiPSC-CMs cells were transiently loaded with the voltage-sensitive dye (VSD) FluoVolt (x0.25, for 30 min at room temperature) in serum-free media (DMEM, Gibco 11 966, supplemented with galactose 10 mM and sodium pyruvate 1 mM). Afterward, the medium containing VSD was replaced by fresh serum-free medium. The multiwell plate was placed in an environmentally controlled stage incubator (37 °C, 5% CO2, water-saturated air atmosphere) (Okolab Inc., Burlingame, CA, USA). The FluoVolt fluorescence signal was recorded from a 0.2 mm × 0.2 mm area using a 40× (NA 0.6) objective lens. Excitation wavelength was 470 ± 10 nm using a light-emitting diode (LED), and emitted light was collected by a photomultiplier (PMT) at 510–560 nm. LED, PMT, associated power supplies, and amplifiers were supplied by Cairn Research Ltd. (Kent, U.K.). The fluorescence signal was digitized at 10 kHz. Acute effects of drugs were assessed by exposure to studied drug concentration with matched vehicle controls (DMSO). A 20 s recording was then taken 5 and 30 min after exposure to the drug or vehicle (DMSO 0.1%) with only one concentration applied per well. The procedure was repeated five times. The records were subsequently analyzed offline using Clampfit software.

    Dopamine Release Assay

    Cell culture and superfusion experiments were performed as described recently with minor modifications.(53)

    Cell Culture

    Human embryonic kidney (HEK) 293 cells were grown in minimum essential medium with Earle’s salts and l-glutamine, 10% heat inactivated fetal bovine serum, and 50 mg/L gentamicin. Cells were grown in 100 or 60 mm diameter tissue culture dishes (polystyrene, Falcon) at 37 °C under an atmosphere of 5% CO2/95% air. The human dopamine transporter/SLC6A3 (DAT) was stably expressed using methods as described previously.(54)

    Superfusion Experiments

    Cells were seeded onto poly-d-lysine-coated 5 mm diameter glass coverslips in 96-well tissue culture plates (3 × 104 cells/well). Two days later cells were loaded with 6 μM [3H] MPP+ (0.2 Ci/mmol) in uptake/superfusion buffer (mmol/L: 4 Tris-HCl; 6.25 4-(2-hydroxyethyl)-1-piperazineethanesulfonic acid (HEPES); 120 NaCl; 5 KCl; 1.2 CaCl2; 1.2 MgSO4; 5.6 d-glucose; 0.5 ascorbic acid; pH 7.1.) at 37 °C for 20 min. After loading, coverslips were transferred to small chambers and superfused (25 °C, 1.0 mL/min) with the uptake buffer mentioned above in a setup as described previously.(55) After a washout period of 45 min to establish a stable efflux of radioactivity the experiment was started with the collection of 4 min fractions. (For determination of a releasing effect 10 μM compound 31e or 3 μM of the reference releaser d-amphetamine was added for three fractions to the superfusion buffer after three fractions of baseline and then removed for another three fractions. For 31e/d-amphetamine interaction experiments 31e was added to the superfusion buffer one fraction before amphetamine after two fractions of baseline.) At the end of the experiment cells were lysed in 1% SDS. The radioactivity in the superfusate fractions and the SDS-lysates was determined by liquid scintillation counting. Release of tritium was expressed as fractional rate; i.e., the radioactivity released during a fraction was expressed as percentage of the total radioactivity present in the cells at the beginning of that fraction.

    Neurite Outgrowth Assay

    Cryopreserved rat cortical neurons (QBM Cell Science, R-Cx-500) were quickly thawed and slowly diluted with neurobasal medium supplemented with l-glutamine (Invitrogen, catalog no. 25030-081), penicillin–streptomycin (Invitrogen, catalog no. 15140-122), and B27 (NB/B27 medium, Invitrogen, catalog no. 17504-044). After a gentle centrifugation step, the neurons were resuspended with NB/B27 medium at a density of 4.0 × 106 cells/mL. One hour prior to treatment, the neurons were plated in 384-well plates (Corning 354663) precoated with a laminin solution (Sigma L2020 1 mg/mL) at a density of 10 000 cells per well. After treatment with test articles and control compounds, the neurons were maintained in a humidified environment at 37 °C with 5% CO2 for 72 h. At the end of the treatment period, the neurons were fixed for 1 h with a 3.7% formaldehyde solution (Acros Organics, 41073-0010). The neurons were washed with phosphate buffered saline (PBS) (SH30264.02) and permeabilized for 10 min with a 0.5% solution of Triton X-100 (Millipore Sigma, X100). After another wash step, the neurons were stained for 1 h with Hoechst 33342 (ThermoFisher Scientific, H3570) and anti-beta III tubulin antibody, Alexa Fluor 488 conjugate (Millipore Sigma AB15708A4) diluted in a blocking buffer solution (Thermo Scientific 37525). Upon completion of the staining step, the neurons were washed again and the plates were sealed in preparation for the imaging process. The neurons were evaluated for neurite outgrowth and cell health using the high content imaging platform, ArrayScan VTi (Thermo Scientific ArrayScan VTi), with an optimized neuronal profiling bioapplication.
    This assay assessed cell health and neurite outgrowth utilizing a neuronal profiling bioapplication applied to images obtained on an ArrayScan VTi. Valid neuron count, mean neurite average length, and neurite total length per neuron were determined and reported. Raw data were normalized to the vehicle control and reported as a normalized % response. Dose–response graphs were generated with GraphPad Prism using a sigmoidal dose–response (variable slope) algorithm.

    In Vivo Pharmacokinetic and Drug Efficacy Studies. Pharmacokinetic Study of 31e

    This study was outsourced to Evotec (Hamburg, Germany). Study dates were as following: acclimation start on November 15, 2018; surgery on November 20, 2018; in-life phase start on November 22, 2018; bioanalytical phase start on December 6 and 7, 2018, and pharmacokinetic reporting on December 10, 2018. All experimental procedures and conditions are available in Supporting Information.

    Microdialysis in Freely Moving Rats

    For microdialysis experiments, male Sprague-Dawley rats (Janvier-Labs, Saint Berthevin, France) weighing 250–350 g were housed under standard laboratory conditions (temperature 22 ± 2 °C, humidity 45–65% with a 12:12 h light-dark cycle lights on at 07:00 h). Animals had free access to food and water. All experimental procedures were approved by the Austrian Animal Experimentation Ethical Committee (Bundesministerium für Wissenschaft, Forschung und Wirtschaft, Kommission für Tierversuchsangelegenheiten) in compliance with international laws and policies.
    A homemade, U-shaped microdialysis probe consisting of a 9 kDa dialysis membrane (Cuprophan, Membrana, Wuppertal, Germany) was stereotaxically implanted under isoflurane (as inhalant: 5% induction; 2.5% maintenance) anesthesia. The probe was positioned according to the stereotaxic atlas of Paxinos and Watson (1998) with its tip reaching into the right nucleus accumbens (NAcb; implantation coordinates: 1.6 mm rostral to bregma, 1.6 mm lateral to the midline, 7.6 mm below the surface of the skull) and fixed to the skull with two jeweler’s screws and dental cement. After surgery, rats received an analgesic (buprenorphine, 5 mg/kg BW, sc) and were individually housed in transparent plexiglas cages. Animals were handled for 5 min twice daily to familiarize them with the experimental procedure and to minimize nonspecific stress responses during the experiment.
    Two days after surgery the microdialysis probe was connected to a syringe mounted onto a microprocessor controlled syringe pump (KD-200 series, KD Scientific Inc., Holliston, MA, USA) via a polyethylene tubing system and superfused with sterile artificial cerebrospinal fluid (aCSF; NaCl 140 mM, KCl 3.0 mM, CaCl2 1.25 mM, MgCl2 1.0 mM, Na2HPO4 1.2 mM, and NaH2PO4 0.3 mM; pH 7.4) at a flow rate of 1.0 μL/min. After an equilibration period of 120 min, consecutive 20 min dialysates were collected directly into ice-cooled microtubes containing 6 μL of an antioxidative mixture (100 mM acetic acid, 0.27 mM Na2EDTA, and 12.5 μM ascorbic acid), vortexed, and stored at −80 °C until further analysis. All microdialysis experiments were started between 07:15 and 07:30. After six baseline samples (collected from −120 to 0 min), vehicle (30% Kolliphor EL) or 31e (1 mg/kg, ip) was administered, and six samples were collected. Subsequently, vehicle (30% Kolliphor EL) or drug was administered at a higher dose (10 mg/kg, ip) and another six microdialysates were collected. During collection of the last two dialysates the probe was perfused with aCSF containing 100 mM KCl in order to elicit local depolarization. At the end of the experiment, rats were euthanized by an overdose of thiopental and brains were removed for histological verification of the placement of microdialysis probes. In all animals, probes were correctly localized within the NAcb.
    Determination of dopamine was performed by reverse-phase high performance liquid chromatography (RP-HPLC) with electrochemical detection as previously described (detection limit: 0.25 fmol/5 μL sample; Camats-Perna et al., 2019).(56) The HPLC system consisted of a Shimadzu (Kyoto, Japan) system controller (CBM-20A), degassing unit (DGU-20A3R), and micro HPLC pump (LC-20ADXR) operated at a flow rate of 0.055 mL/min coupled with an Antec Decade II electrochemical detector (Antec Zoeterwoude, The Netherlands) set at +460 mV. The analytical column (NeuroSep 105; 50 mm × 1 mm, 3 μm spherical particles; Antec, Zoeterwoude, The Netherlands) was coupled directly to a Antec SenCell 2 mm glassy carbon working electrode (Antec Zoeterwoude, The Netherlands). The column and detector cell were maintained at 35 °C by a column oven as part of the electrochemical detector. Samples of 5 μL were automatically injected by a SIL-20ACXR refrigerated autosampler (Shimadzu, Japan). The mobile phase consisted of 7% (v/v) methanol, 50 mM phosphoric acid, 50 mM citric acid, 2.36 mM octane–sulfonic acid, 0.1 mM Na2EDTA at a pH of 5.6 that was filtered (0.2 μm) before use. Evaluation of dopamine was carried out by comparing peak areas of samples with a set of external standard solutions (range between 100 pM and 5 nM) by using Lab Solution chromatography software (LabSolution CS, Shimadzu, Japan).
    The DA content in each 20 min microdialysate was expressed as relative value to the mean absolute DA content of the three samples preceding the first administration of drug or vehicle. Data are presented as the mean ± SEM. Statistical analysis was performed with Statistica Software version 13 (StatSoft GmbH, Hamburg, Germany) using a two-way ANOVA with repeated measurements followed by Fisher’s LSD test. P < 0.05 was considered statistically significant.

    References

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To

    This article references 56 other publications.

    1. 1
      Minzenberg, M. J.; Carter, C. S. Modafinil: A review of neurochemical actions and effects on cognition. Neuropsychopharmacology 2008, 33 (7), 1477– 1502,  DOI: 10.1038/sj.npp.1301534
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      1
      Modafinil: A Review of Neurochemical Actions and Effects on Cognition
      Minzenberg, Michael J.; Carter, Cameron S.
      Neuropsychopharmacology (2008), 33 (7), 1477-1502CODEN: NEROEW; ISSN:0893-133X. (Nature Publishing Group)
      A review. Modafinil (2-[(Diphenylmethyl) sulfinyl] acetamide, Provigil) is an FDA-approved medication with wake-promoting properties. Pre-clin. studies of modafinil suggest a complex profile of neurochem. and behavioral effects, distinct from those of amphetamine. In addn., modafinil shows initial promise for a variety of off-label indications in psychiatry, including treatment-resistant depression, attention-deficit/hyperactivity disorder, and schizophrenia. Cognitive dysfunction may be a particularly important emerging treatment target for modafinil, across these and other neuropsychiatric disorders. We aimed to comprehensively review the empirical literature on neurochem. actions of modafinil, and effects on cognition in animal models, healthy adult humans, and clin. populations. We searched PubMed with the search term modafinil' and reviewed all English-language articles for neurochem., neurophysiol., cognitive, or information-processing exptl. measures. We addnl. summarized the pharmacokinetic profile of modafinil and clin. efficacy in psychiatric patients. Modafinil exhibits robust effects on catecholamines, serotonin, glutamate, gamma amino-butyric acid, orexin, and histamine systems in the brain. Many of these effects may be secondary to catecholamine effects, with some selectivity for cortical over subcortical sites of action. In addn., modafinil (at well-tolerated doses) improves function in several cognitive domains, including working memory and episodic memory, and other processes dependent on prefrontal cortex and cognitive control. These effects are obsd. in rodents, healthy adults, and across several psychiatric disorders. Furthermore, modafinil appears to be well-tolerated, with a low rate of adverse events and a low liability to abuse. Modafinil has a no. of neurochem. actions in the brain, which may be related to primary effects on catecholaminergic systems. These effects are in general advantageous for cognitive processes. Overall, modafinil is an excellent candidate agent for remediation of cognitive dysfunction in neuropsychiatric disorders. Neuropsychopharmacol. (2008) 33, 1477-1502; doi:10.1038/sj.npp.1301534; published online 22 August 2007.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD1cXlvVSrtrc%253D&md5=b3f5ab7df9e6126e05e19a352900b482
    2. 2
      Gerrard, P.; Malcolm, R. Mechanisms of modafinil: a review of current research. Neuropsychiatr. Dis. Treat. 2007, 3 (3), 349– 364
      [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      2
      Mechanisms of modafinil: a review of current research
      Gerrard, Paul; Malcolm, Robert
      Neuropsychiatric Disease and Treatment (2007), 3 (3), 349-364CODEN: NDTEAZ; ISSN:1176-6328. (Dove Medical Press (NZ) Ltd.)
      A review. The novel wake-promoting agent modafinil has been in use for the treatment of several sleep disorders for a few years and is now undergoing clin. trials for its use in the treatment of stimulant addiction, but its primary mechanism of action remains elusive. Previous lab. studies have shown that modafinil has antioxidative and neuroprotective effects, which have not previously been suggested to be related to its wake-promoting effects. However, recent research indicates that free radicals may be related to sleep induction as well as cellular damage, suggesting that a common target of action may mediate modafinil's ability to oppose both of these effects. In this review we summarize and discuss previously published research on modafinil's neural, cytoprotective, and cognitive effects, and we propose possible primary biochem. targets that could underlie the effects of modafinil obsd. in these studies. We also suggest neurocognitive mechanisms responsible for modafinil's cognitive enhancing effects and its therapeutic potential in the treatment of stimulant addiction.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD2sXps1WnsLw%253D&md5=3b9d1c81db02be3d8ecf8c370208bddf
    3. 3
      Urban, K. R.; Gao, W. J. Performance enhancement at the cost of potential brain plasticity: neural ramifications of nootropic drugs in the healthy developing brain. Front. Syst. Neurosci. 2014, 8, 38,  DOI: 10.3389/fnsys.2014.00038
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      3
      Performance enhancement at the cost of potential brain plasticity: neural ramifications of nootropic drugs in the healthy developing brain
      Urban Kimberly R; Gao Wen-Jun
      Frontiers in systems neuroscience (2014), 8 (), 38 ISSN:1662-5137.
      Cognitive enhancement is perhaps one of the most intriguing and controversial topics in neuroscience today. Currently, the main classes of drugs used as potential cognitive enhancers include psychostimulants (methylphenidate (MPH), amphetamine), but wakefulness-promoting agents (modafinil) and glutamate activators (ampakine) are also frequently used. Pharmacologically, substances that enhance the components of the memory/learning circuits-dopamine, glutamate (neuronal excitation), and/or norepinephrine-stand to improve brain function in healthy individuals beyond their baseline functioning. In particular, non-medical use of prescription stimulants such as MPH and illicit use of psychostimulants for cognitive enhancement have seen a recent rise among teens and young adults in schools and college campuses. However, this enhancement likely comes with a neuronal, as well as ethical, cost. Altering glutamate function via the use of psychostimulants may impair behavioral flexibility, leading to the development and/or potentiation of addictive behaviors. Furthermore, dopamine and norepinephrine do not display linear effects; instead, their modulation of cognitive and neuronal function maps on an inverted-U curve. Healthy individuals run the risk of pushing themselves beyond optimal levels into hyperdopaminergic and hypernoradrenergic states, thus vitiating the very behaviors they are striving to improve. Finally, recent studies have begun to highlight potential damaging effects of stimulant exposure in healthy juveniles. This review explains how the main classes of cognitive enhancing drugs affect the learning and memory circuits, and highlights the potential risks and concerns in healthy individuals, particularly juveniles and adolescents. We emphasize the performance enhancement at the potential cost of brain plasticity that is associated with the neural ramifications of nootropic drugs in the healthy developing brain.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A280%3ADC%252BC2cflvFamsg%253D%253D&md5=d552cabbeece23291f10b62d98deb3fc
    4. 4
      Murphy, H. M.; Ekstrand, D.; Tarchick, M.; Wideman, C. H. Modafinil as a cognitive enhancer of spatial working memory in rats. Physiol. Behav. 2015, 142, 126– 130,  DOI: 10.1016/j.physbeh.2015.02.003
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      4
      Modafinil as a cognitive enhancer of spatial working memory in rats
      Murphy, Helen M.; Ekstrand, Dylan; Tarchick, Matthew; Wideman, Cyrilla H.
      Physiology & Behavior (2015), 142 (), 126-130CODEN: PHBHA4; ISSN:0031-9384. (Elsevier)
      The present expt. examd. the influence of modafinil on working memory in rats. Control and exptl. rats were placed in cages equipped with a running wheel. The study was divided into three periods: 1. habituation, 2. exptl. - in which modafinil was orally administered to exptl. animals, and 3. withdrawal. Spatial working memory was tested utilizing the Morris Water Maze. Animals were given two trials in each session: 1. a sample trial in which they discovered the location of the platform and 2. a test trial in which they recalled the location of the platform. Platform placement and starting place location of the rats were changed every session. Performance of control animals during sample trials and test trials showed no difference in time to reach the platform; whereas, exptl. animals demonstrated faster attainment of the goal during the test trial. In withdrawal, there was no difference in time between the two trials for exptl. animals. Wheel running activity of the exptl. group was lower than that of the control group during the exptl. period. This study supports the hypothesis that modafinil has a pos. effect on working memory in rats. It is suggested that benefits of modafinil can extend beyond its prescribed usage; however, these advantages of modafinil use should be addressed in discussions related to ethical concerns assocd. with neuroenhancers.

      Cao, J.; Slack, R. D.; Bakare, O. M.; Burzynski, C.; Rais, R.; Slusher, B. S.; Kopajtic, T.; Bonifazi, A.; Ellenberger, M. P.; Yano, H.; He, Y.; Bi, G. H.; Xi, Z. H.; Loland, C. J.; Newman, A.       6
      Novel and High Affinity 2-[(Diphenylmethyl)sulfinyl]acetamide (Modafinil) Analogues as Atypical Dopamine Transporter Inhibitors
      Cao, Jianjing; Slack, Rachel D.; Bakare, Oluyomi M.; Burzynski, Caitlin; Rais, Rana; Slusher, Barbara S.; Kopajtic, Theresa; Bonifazi, Alessandro; Ellenberger, Michael P.; Yano, Hideaki; He, Yi; Bi, Guo-Hua; Xi, Zheng-Xiong; Loland, Claus J.; Newman, Amy Hauck
      Journal of Medicinal Chemistry (2016), 59 (23), 10676-10691CODEN: JMCMAR; ISSN:0022-2623. (American Chemical Society)
      The development of pharmacotherapeutic treatments of psychostimulant abuse has remained a challenge, despite significant efforts made toward relevant mechanistic targets, such as the dopamine transporter (DAT). The atypical DAT inhibitors have received attention due to their promising pharmacol. profiles in animal models of cocaine and methamphetamine abuse. Herein the authors report a series of modafinil analogs that have an atypical DAT inhibitor profile. The authors extended SAR by chem. manipulating the oxidn. states of the sulfoxide and the amide functional groups, halogenating the Ph rings, and/or functionalizing the terminal nitrogen with substituted piperazines, resulting in several novel leads such as 1-(4-(2-((bis(4-fluorophenyl)methyl)sulfinyl)ethyl)piperazin-1-yl)-3-phenylpropan-2-ol (compd. 11b), which demonstrated high DAT affinity (Ki = 2.5 nM) and selectivity without producing concomitant locomotor stimulation in mice, as compared to cocaine. These results are consistent with an atypical DAT inhibitor profile and suggest that 11b may be a potential lead for development as a psychostimulant abuse medication.

      An Overview of the Clinical Uses, Pharmacology, and Safety of Modafinil
      Murillo-Rodriguez, Eric; Barciela Veras, Andre; Barbosa Rocha, Nuno; Budde, Henning; Machado, Sergio
      ACS Chemical Neuroscience (2018), 9 (2), 151-158CODEN: ACNCDM; ISSN:1948-7193. (American Chemical Society)
      A review. Modafinil (MOD) is a drug used for the management of excessive daytime sleepiness obsd. in several sleep disturbances such as shift work sleep disorder, obstructive sleep apnea, restless leg syndrome and narcolepsy. Addnl., a wide scope of medical uses of MOD have been described such as fatigue in subjects with depression as well as patients under chemotherapy. Moreover, there also appear to be a cognitive enhancer drug. In contrast, recent reports have indicated the risk of developing addiction to MOD. Furthermore, interest of studying potential long-term effects of MOD have raised. Here, the authors highlight the evidence concerning the medical uses of MOD in the management of sleepiness, fatigue assocd. with depression and cancer as well as combat depletion.

      Dinges, D. F.; Arora, S.; Darwish, M.; Niebler, G. E. Pharmacodynamic effects on alertness of single doses of armodafinil in healthy subjects during a nocturnal period of acute sleep loss. Curr. Med. Res. Opin. 2006, 22 (1), 159– 167,  DOI: 10.1185/030079906X80378
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      9
      Pharmacodynamic effects on alertness of single doses of armodafinil in healthy subjects during a nocturnal period of acute sleep loss
      Dinges, David F.; Arora, Sanjay; Darwish, Mona; Niebler, Gwendolyn E.
      Current Medical Research and Opinion (2006), 22 (1), 159-167CODEN: CMROCX; ISSN:0300-7995. (LibraPharm Ltd.)
      To assess the pharmacodynamics of armodafinil compared with modafinil and placebo on measures of alertness in healthy volunteers undergoing sleep loss, a double-blind, active- and placebo-controlled, parallel-group study was conducted on, 107 healthy male volunteers (aged 18-40 years) randomized to receive a single oral dose of armodafinil (100, 150, 200, or 300 mg), modafinil (200 mg) or placebo administered at 19:25 h. The primary outcome was the Maintenance of Wakefulness Test (MWT), administered every 2 h from 22:00-08:00 h. Secondary outcomes included the Psychomotor Vigilance Task (PVT) and the Karolinska Sleepiness Scale. Blood samples for pharmacokinetic anal. were collected hourly. Adverse events were evaluated throughout the 2-day lab. stay and by telephone on day 9. All four doses of armodafinil and the 200 mg dose of modafinil improved wakefulness as measured by increased MWT latencies (treatment effect, p < 0.0001) and reduced PVT lapses of attention (treatment effect, p < 0.0001). The magnitude and duration of these effects at the later time points appeared to be dose- and concn.-dependent. Armodafinil at 200 mg resulted in comparable Cmax, a later tmax, and higher plasma concns. 6-14 h post-drug administration than with 200 mg modafinil. Following armodafinil, longer MWT latencies and fewer PVT lapses 6-14 h post-drug administration were obsd. compared with modafinil. Armodafinil doses were well tolerated, with the most common adverse events including abdominal pain, nausea, and headache. There were reports of tachycardia/palpitations. Decreased mean sleep efficiency and increased mean blood pressure were also obsd. Armodafinil improved alertness at all doses studied. Relative to modafinil 200 mg, armodafinil 200 mg showed a comparable peak plasma concn. with higher concns. 6-14 h post-drug, and improved wakefulness and sustained attention for a longer time post-dose. Both drugs were well tolerated; however, further research on the efficacy, safety, and tolerability of armodafinil in patients with disorders of excessive sleepiness (ES) is required.

      Volkow, N. D.; Fowler, J. S.; Logan, J.; Alexoff, D.; Zhu, W.; Telang, F.; Wang, G. J.; Jayne, M.; Hooker, J. Effects of modafinil on dopamine and dopamine transporters in the male human brain: clinical implications. JAMA 2009, 301, 1148– 1154,  DOI: 10.1001/jama.2009.351
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      10
      Effects of modafinil on dopamine and dopamine transporters in the male human brain. Clinical implications
      Volkow, Nora D.; Fowler, Joanna S.; Logan, Jean; Alexoff, David; Zhu, Wei; Telang, Frank; Wang, Gene-Jack; Jayne, Millard; Hooker, Jacob M.; Wong, Christopher; Hubbard, Barbara; Carter, Pauline; Warner, Donald; King, Payton; Shea, Colleen; Xu, Youwen; Muench, Lisa; Apelskog-Torres, Karen
      JAMA, the Journal of the American Medical Association (2009), 301 (11), 1148-1154CODEN: JAMAAP; ISSN:0098-7484. (American Medical Association)
      Modafinil, a wake-promoting drug used to treat narcolepsy, is increasingly being used as a cognitive enhancer. Although initially launched as distinct from stimulants that increase extracellular dopamine by targeting dopamine transporters, recent preclin. studies suggest otherwise. Objective was to measure the acute effects of modafinil at doses used therapeutically (200 mg and 400 mg given orally) on extracellular dopamine and on dopamine transporters in the male human brain. Design, Setting, and Participants Positron emission tomog. with [11C]raclopride (D2/D3 radioligand sensitive to changes in endogenous dopamine) and [11C]cocaine (dopamine transporter radioligand) was used to measure the effects of modafinil on extracellular dopamine and on dopamine transporters in 10 healthy male participants. The study took place over an 8-mo period (2007-2008) at Brookhaven National Lab. Main Outcome Measures Primary outcomes were changes in dopamine D2/D3 receptor and dopamine transporter availability (measured by changes in binding potential) after modafinil when compared with after placebo. Modafinil decreased mean (SD) [11C]raclopride binding potential in caudate (6.1% [6.5%]; 95% confidence interval [CI], 1.5% to 10.8%; P =.02), putamen (6.7% [4.9%]; 95% CI, 3.2% to 10.3%; P =.002), and nucleus accumbens (19.4% [20%]; 95% CI, 5% to 35%; P =.02), reflecting increases in extracellular dopamine. Modafinil also decreased [11C]cocaine binding potential in caudate (53.8% [13.8%]; 95% CI, 43.9% to 63.6%; P <.001), putamen (47.2% [11.4%]; 95% CI, 39.1% to 55.4%; P <.001), and nucleus accumbens (39.3% [10%]; 95% CI, 30% to 49%; P =.001), reflecting occupancy of dopamine transporters. In this pilot study, modafinil blocked dopamine transporters and increased dopamine in the human brain (including the nucleus accumbens). Because drugs that increase dopamine in the nucleus accumbens have the potential for abuse, and considering the increasing use of modafinil, these results highlight the need for heightened awareness for potential abuse of and dependence on modafinil in vulnerable populations.
      >> More from SciFinder ®

      Madras, B. K.; Xie, Z.; Lin, Z.; Jassen, A.; Panas, H.; Lynch, L.; Johnson, R.; Livni, E.; Spencer, T. J.; Bonab, A. A.; Miller, G. M.; Fischman, A. J. Modafinil occupies dopamine and norepinephrine transporters in vivo and modulates the transporters and trace amine activity in vitro. J. Pharmacol. Exp. Ther. 2006, 319 (2), 561– 569,  DOI: 10.1124/jpet.106.106583
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      12
      Modafinil occupies dopamine and norepinephrine transporters in vivo and modulates the transporters and trace amine activity in vitro
      Madras, Bertha K.; Xie, Zhihua; Lin, Zhicheng; Jassen, Amy; Panas, Helen; Lynch, Laurie; Johnson, Ryan; Livni, Eli; Spencer, Thomas J.; Bonab, Ali A.; Miller, Gregory M.; Fischman, Alan J.
      Journal of Pharmacology and Experimental Therapeutics (2006), 319 (2), 561-569CODEN: JPETAB; ISSN:0022-3565. (American Society for Pharmacology and Experimental Therapeutics)
      2-[(Diphenylmethyl)sulfinyl]acetamide (modafinil), prescribed principally to treat narcolepsy, is undergoing assessment for other neuropsychiatric disorders and medical conditions. The neurochem. substrates of modafinil are unresolved. We postulated that modafinil enhances wakefulness by modulating dopamine (DAT), norepinephrine (NET), or serotonin (SERT) transporter activities. In vivo, we detd. DAT and NET occupancy by modafinil by positron emission tomog. imaging; in vitro, we detd. modafinil activity at the DAT, NET, SERT, and rhesus monkey trace amine receptor 1 (TA1). In rhesus monkey, modafinil occupancy of striatal DAT was detected by [11C]2β-carbomethoxy-3β-4-(fluorophenyl)tropane and of thalamic NET by [11C](S,S)-2-(α-(2-methoxyphenoxy)-benzyl)morpholine. In vitro, modafinil effects in DAT-human embryonic kidney (HEK), NET-HEK, and SERT-HEK cells were investigated alone or combined with the TA1 receptor. Modafinil (i.v.) occupied striatal DAT sites (5 mg/kg: 35±12%, n = 4; 8 mg/kg: 54±3%, n = 3). In thalamus, modafinil occupied NET sites (5 mg/kg: 16±7.8%, n = 6; 8 mg/kg: 44±12%; n = 2). In vitro, modafinil inhibited [3H]dopamine (IC50 = 6.4 μM), [3H]norepinephrine (IC50 = 35.6 μM), and [3H]serotonin (IC50 > 500 μM) transport via the human DAT, NET, and SERT. Modafinil did not activate the TA1 receptor in TA1-HEK cells, but it augmented a monoamine transporter-dependent enhancement of phenethylamine activation of TA1 in TA1-DAT and TA1-NET cells, but not in TA1-SERT cells. The present data provide compelling evidence that modafinil occupies the DAT and NET in living brain of rhesus monkeys and raise the possibility that modafinil affects wakefulness by interacting with catecholamine transporters in brain.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD28XhtFOkur3N&md5=6e0b14f53f5bb138f63f21e19e3939ac
    13. 13
      Zolkowska, D.; Jain, R.; Rothman, R. B.; Partilla, J. S.; Roth, B. L.; Setola, V.; Prisinzano, T. E.; Baumann, M. H. Evidence for the involvement of dopamine transporters in the behavioral stimulant effects of modafinil. J. Pharmacol. Exp. Ther. 2009, 329, 738– 746,  DOI: 10.1124/jpet.108.146142
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      13
      Evidence for the involvement of dopamine transporters in behavioral stimulant effects of modafinil
      Zolkowska, Dorota; Jain, Raka; Rothman, Richard B.; Partilla, John S.; Roth, Bryan L.; Setola, Vincent; Prisinzano, Thomas E.; Baumann, Michael H.
      Journal of Pharmacology and Experimental Therapeutics (2009), 329 (2), 738-746CODEN: JPETAB; ISSN:0022-3565. (American Society for Pharmacology and Experimental Therapeutics)
      Modafinil is prescribed for numerous medical conditions, but the drug's mechanism of action is unclear. Here, we examd. the interaction of modafinil with receptors and transporters in vitro and compared pharmacol. effects of the drug with those produced by indirect dopamine (DA) agonists 1-[2-[bis(4-fluorophenyl)methoxy]ethyl]-4-(3-phenylpropyl)piperazine (GBR12909) and (+)-methamphetamine (METH). Modafinil was screened at various receptors and transporters using binding assays. Transporter-mediated uptake and release were examd. in rat brain synaptosomes. Effects of modafinil on motor activity and neurochem. were detd. in rats undergoing in vivo microdialysis in nucleus accumbens. Of the receptors and transporters assayed, modafinil displayed measurable potency only at DA transporters (DAT), inhibiting [3H]DA uptake, with an IC50 value of 4.0 μM. Accordingly, modafinil pretreatment (10 μM) antagonized METH-induced release of the DAT substrate [3H]1-methyl-4-phenylpyridinium. I.v. modafinil (20 and 60 mg/kg) produced dose-dependent increases in motor activity and extracellular DA, without affecting serotonin (5-HT). Analogous results were obsd. for GBR12909 (1 and 3 mg/kg), whereas METH (0.3 and 1 mg/kg) increased DA and 5-HT. Locomotor effects of all drugs were pos. correlated with dialyzate DA (P < 0.001). Interestingly, modafinil pretreatment reduced METH-induced ambulation and DA release. Our data show that modafinil interacts with DAT sites in rat brain, a property shared with agonist medications under investigation for treating cocaine dependence. Nondopaminergic mechanisms may also contribute to the pharmacol. of modafinil. Finally, the results suggest that modafinil should be tested as an adjunct for treating METH addiction.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD1MXlt1OlsL4%253D&md5=0c5af6285ed23382c46a0d35bafbaa3b
    14. 14
      Loland, J. C.; Mereu, M.; Okunola, O.; Cao, J.; Prisinzano, T. E.; Mazier, S.; Kopajtic, T.; Shi, L.; Katz, J. L.; Tanda, G.; Newman, A. H. R-Modafinil (armodafinil): a unique dopamine uptake inhibitor and potential medication for psychostimulant abuse. Biol. Psychiatry 2012, 72, 405– 413,  DOI: 10.1016/j.biopsych.2012.03.022
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      14
      R-Modafinil (Armodafinil): A Unique Dopamine Uptake Inhibitor and Potential Medication for Psychostimulant Abuse
      Loland, Claus J.; Mereu, Maddalena; Okunola, Oluyomi M.; Cao, Jianjing; Prisinzano, Thomas E.; Mazier, Sonia; Kopajtic, Theresa; Shi, Lei; Katz, Jonathan L.; Tanda, Gianluigi; Newman, Amy Hauck
      Biological Psychiatry (2012), 72 (5), 405-413CODEN: BIPCBF; ISSN:0006-3223. (Elsevier)
      (±)-Modafinil has piqued interest as a treatment for attention-deficit/hyperactivity disorder and stimulant dependence. The R-enantiomer of modafinil might have unique pharmacol. properties that should be further investigated. (±)-Modafinil and its R-(-)- and S-(+)-enantiomers were synthesized and tested for inhibition of [3H] dopamine (DA) uptake and [3H]WIN 35428 binding in human dopamine transporter (DAT) wild-type and mutants with altered conformational equil. Data were compared with cocaine and the atypical DA uptake inhibitor, JHW 007. R- and S-modafinil were also evaluated in microdialysis studies in the mouse nucleus accumbens shell and in a cocaine discrimination procedure. (±)-, R-, and S-modafinil bind to the DAT and inhibit DA uptake less potently than cocaine, with R-modafinil having approx. threefold higher affinity than its S-enantiomer. Mol. docking studies revealed subtle differences in binding modes for the enantiomers. R-modafinil was significantly less potent in the DAT Y156F mutant compared with wild-type DAT, whereas S-modafinil was affected less. Studies with the Y335A DAT mutant showed that the R- and S-enantiomers tolerated the inward-facing conformation better than cocaine, which was further supported by [2-(trimethylammonium)ethyl]-methanethiosulfonate reactivity on the DAT E2C I159C. Microdialysis studies demonstrated that both R- and S-modafinil produced increases in extracellular DA concns. in the nucleus accumbens shell less efficaciously than cocaine and with a longer duration of action. Both enantiomers fully substituted in mice trained to discriminate cocaine from saline.R-modafinil displays an in vitro profile different from cocaine. Future trials with R-modafinil as a substitute therapy with the potential benefit of cognitive enhancement for psychostimulant addiction are warranted.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC38XmtFelt74%253D&md5=78808210fc68d2fbcdd97190f03b63d0
    15. 15
      Rasetti, R.; Mattay, V. S.; Stankevich, B.; Skjei, K.; Blasi, G.; Sambataro, F.; Arrillaga-Romany, I. C.; Goldberg, T. E.; Callicott, J. H.; Apud, J. A.; Weinberger, D. R. Modulatory effects of modafinil on neural circuits regulating emotion and cognition. Neuropsychopharmacology 2010, 35 (10), 2101– 2109,  DOI: 10.1038/npp.2010.83
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      15
      Modulatory Effects of Modafinil on Neural Circuits Regulating Emotion and Cognition
      Rasetti, Roberta; Mattay, Venkata S.; Stankevich, Beth; Skjei, Kelsey; Blasi, Giuseppe; Sambataro, Fabio; Arrillaga-Romany, Isabel C.; Goldberg, Terry E.; Callicott, Joseph H.; Apud, Jose A.; Weinberger, Daniel R.
      Neuropsychopharmacology (2010), 35 (10), 2101-2109CODEN: NEROEW; ISSN:0893-133X. (Nature Publishing Group)
      Modafinil differs from other arousal-enhancing agents in chem. structure, neurochem. profile, and behavioral effects. Most functional neuroimaging studies to date examd. the effect of modafinil only on information processing underlying executive cognition, but cognitive enhancers in general have been shown to have pronounced effects on emotional behavior, too. We examd. the effect of modafinil on neural circuits underlying affective processing and cognitive functions. Healthy volunteers were enrolled in this double-blinded placebo-controlled trial (100 mg/day for 7 days). They underwent BOLD fMRI while performing an emotion information-processing task that activates the amygdala and two prefrontally dependent cognitive tasks-a working memory (WM) task and a variable attentional control (VAC) task. A clin. assessment that included measurement of blood pressure, heart rate, the Hamilton anxiety scale, and the profile of mood state (POMS) questionnaire was also performed on each test day. BOLD fMRI revealed significantly decreased amygdala reactivity to fearful stimuli on modafinil compared with the placebo condition. During executive cognition tasks, a WM task and a VAC task, modafinil reduced BOLD signal in the prefrontal cortex and anterior cingulate. Although not statistically significant, there were trends for reduced anxiety, for decreased fatigue-inertia and increased vigor-activity, as well as decreased anger-hostility on modafinil. Modafinil in low doses has a unique physiol. profile compared with stimulant drugs: it enhances the efficiency of prefrontal cortical cognitive information processing, while dampening reactivity to threatening stimuli in the amygdala, a brain region implicated in anxiety. Neuropsychopharmacol. (2010) 35, 2101-2109; doi:10.1038/npp.2010.83; published online 16 June 2010.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC3cXhtVajs7nM&md5=858c640f72c28500903e23ec8691c32e
    16. 16
      Lin, J. S.; Gervasoni, D.; Hou, Y.; Vanni-Mercier, G.; Rambert, F.; Frydman, A.; Jouvet, M. Effects of amphetamine and modafinil on the sleep/wake cycle during experimental hypersomnia induced by sleep deprivation in the cat. Journal of Sleep Research 2000, 9 (1), 89– 96,  DOI: 10.1046/j.1365-2869.2000.00181.x
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      16
      Effects of amphetamine and modafinil on the sleep/wake cycle during experimental hypersomnia induced by sleep deprivation in the cat
      Lin J S; Gervasoni D; Hou Y; Vanni-Mercier G; Rambert F; Frydman A; Jouvet M
      Journal of sleep research (2000), 9 (1), 89-96 ISSN:0962-1105.
      Modafinil is a newly discovered waking substance now being used in the treatment of hypersomnia and narcolepsy. We have shown previously in the cat that, unlike amphetamine, modafinil induces long-lasting wakefulness (W) without behavioral excitation and subsequent sleep rebound, and that its waking effect does not depend on endogenous catecholamines. To further characterize the awakening properties of modafinil and current psychostimulants in experimental models of hypersomnia, we examined the effect of oral administration of placebo, modafinil (5 mg kg-1) or amphetamine (1 mg kg-1) on the sleep/wake cycle and power spectral density (PSD) in cats after an 18-h water-tank sleep deprivation period. We found that the placebo had no effect on the dynamics of sleep recovery, while both modafinil and amphetamine induced suppression of cortical slow activity and a waking state lasting 6-8 h. After the amphetamine-induced waking period, both deep slow wave sleep (SWS2) and paradoxical sleep (PS) occurred in greater amounts than after placebo and the PSD during SWS was also increased. Thus, the cumulative time spent in W during a 48-h period was similar to that with placebo, indicating enhanced sleep rebound. In contrast, after the modafinil-induced W, the occurrence and evolution of SWS2 or PS, as well as the PSD during SWS, were similar to those seen with placebo during the same period, so that the total time spent in W in a 48-h period remained significantly higher than the control level, indicating no additional sleep rebound. These results indicate that modafinil is effective against somnolence and hypersomnia and does not produce a subsequent increase in sleep and suggest that the pharmacological profile of modafinil is different from that of amphetamine.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A280%3ADC%252BD3c7pvVGisQ%253D%253D&md5=a4cbd00ad9ad933bd9fbbef887a23861

      Kim, D. Practical use and risk of modafinil, a novel waking drug. Environ. Health Toxicol. 2012, 27, e2012007,  DOI: 10.5620/eht.2012.27.e2012007
      [Crossref], [PubMed], Google Scholar

    18. 18
      Avelar, A. J.; Cao, J.; Newman, A. H.; Beckstead, M. J. Atypical dopamine transporter inhibitors R-modafinil and JHW 007 differentially affect D2 autoreceptor neurotransmission and the firing rate of midbrain dopamine neurons. Neuropharmacology 2017, 123, 410– 419,  DOI: 10.1016/j.neuropharm.2017.06.016
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      18
      Atypical dopamine transporter inhibitors R-modafinil and JHW 007 differentially affect D2 autoreceptor neurotransmission and the firing rate of midbrain dopamine neurons
      Avelar, Alicia J.; Cao, Jianjing; Newman, Amy Hauck; Beckstead, Michael J.
      Neuropharmacology (2017), 123 (), 410-419CODEN: NEPHBW; ISSN:0028-3908. (Elsevier B.V.)
      Abuse of psychostimulants like cocaine that inhibit dopamine (DA) reuptake through the dopamine transporter (DAT) represents a major public health issue, however FDA-approved pharmacotherapies have yet to be developed. Recently a class of ligands termed "atypical DAT inhibitors" has gained attention due to their range of effectiveness in increasing extracellular DA levels without demonstrating significant abuse liability. These compds. not only hold promise as therapeutic agents to treat stimulant use disorders but also as exptl. tools to improve our understanding of DAT function. Here we used patch clamp electrophysiol. in mouse brain slices to explore the effects of two atypical DAT inhibitors (R-modafinil and JHW 007) on the physiol. of single DA neurons in the substantia nigra and ventral tegmental area. Despite their commonalities of being DAT inhibitors that lack cocaine-like behavioral profiles, these compds. exhibited surprisingly divergent cellular effects. Similar to cocaine, R-modafinil slowed DA neuron firing in a D2 receptor-dependent manner and rapidly enhanced the amplitude and duration of D2 receptor-mediated currents in the midbrain. In contrast, JHW 007 exhibited little effect on firing, slow DAT blockade, and an unexpected inhibition of D2 receptor-mediated currents that may be due to direct D2 receptor antagonism. Furthermore, pretreatment with JHW 007 blunted the cellular effects of cocaine, suggesting that it may be valuable to investigate similar DAT inhibitors as potential therapeutic agents. Further exploration of these and other atypical DAT inhibitors may reveal important cellular effects of compds. that will have potential as pharmacotherapies for treating cocaine use disorders.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC2sXhtVOjt7zN&md5=6001c7f27aa797f25eae9fe3ee9884a7

      SARs at the Monoamine Transporters for a Novel Series of Modafinil Analogues
      Cao, Jianjing; Prisinzano, Thomas E.; Okunola, Oluyomi M.; Kopajtic, Theresa; Shook, Matthew; Katz, Jonathan L.; Hauck Newman, Amy
      ACS Medicinal Chemistry Letters (2011), 2 (1), 48-52CODEN: AMCLCT; ISSN:1948-5875. (American Chemical Society)
      A series of modafinil (1) analogs were synthesized wherein (1) para-halo-substitutents were added to the aryl rings, (2) the sulfoxide function was removed, and (3) the primary amide group was replaced with secondary and tertiary amides and amines to investigate the effects of these chem. modifications on dopamine transporter, serotonin transporter, and norepinephrine transporter binding. In addn., the locomotor-stimulant effects in mice of (±)-modafinil (1) (I), its R- and S-enantiomers, and its para-chloro sulfinylacetamide analog (5c) (II) were compared to those of cocaine.
